social_posts.post_text:
I’ve tried to type this caption out multiple times but each time fell short of capturing how I truly feel— deep deep gratitude

In 2020 I dropped out of nursing school to build an online business that I had started in Dec of 2019 with… 

>no experience, I was in school for health not business or marketing or finance
>no big connections, really hardly any connections at all (small town gal)
>little money in my bank account

But what I did have was a crazy passion and drive 

Looking back I wish I could hug that girl. The one who was brave enough to start something new and the one who was brave enough to drop out of school to do something she really really loved

Why? Because I wouldn’t be able to be here today writing this caption and saying that what’s been achieved this month is beyond her wildest dreams (& it’s only just the beginning) 

But my story isn’t an overnight success… I went from going to college while working as a nanny and building a business making $1k a month to dropping out and taking my business full time to still only make $1k a month. 

It wasn’t until a year after taking my business full time that everything started to change. My Instagram started to grow, I left NWM and started the business that you see and know today, and in the process of it all it lead me to a career that sets my soul on fire

It’s been the wildest of rides learning and growing but it’s one that I wouldn’t trade for anything. 

Whether you’ve been here since day 1 or 1 day, thank you🫶🏻 you truly mean the world to me— without your support I wouldn’t be where I am today or have the life I have. You’ve helped make my dreams come true and I am forever grateful

& here are a few live ideas for you:

-go live with someone else in your niche (collaboration)
-host a live Q&A
-go live and share your story/background 
-go live and talk about your bestselling offers
-share bts of your workspace
-do a product unboxing
-go live with a student in one of your offers and talk about their experience with the offer
-host a mini training on live
-do hot seat coaching
-celebrate a milestone and share what you’ve learned along the way or something you wish you would’ve known earlier

Challenge for you: create a business wrapped post (stories or feed post) for your own business! This is a fun and creative way to show off your offers, connect with your audience, and reflect on your year🫶🏻

>>>If you create a business wrapped post, tag me so I can see what you’ve been up to this year😍

From nursing school to college dropout to network marketing to starting my own business (with no background or schooling in business) it’s been a heck of a ride and I’ve loved every single second of it— good and bad

How did your business journey start? Let me know in the comments⬇️

Instagram stories👀

This is easily the most under-strategized and underutilized content format on instagram

Yes, your feed is important. Yes, optimize your bio. Yes, update your highlights. 

But what about your stories? 

As a business owner, your stories aren’t just for reposting feed content and sharing a picture of your dog (yes that can be on there but shouldn’t be the only thing)

Your stories should take people on a journey, sell your offers, connect, and they definitely should have a strategy!

I personally believe that stories are one of thee most powerful places to sell yet SO MANY PEOPLE aren’t taking advantage of it!

Something that has been a game changer in my business is selling everyday on stories (expect Sundays cuz I always take Sundays off)

Here are 5 ideas to get you started:
1- take a picture of your zoom before hoping on a call with a client. After the client call share something that you covered in that call (takeaways, aha-moments, lessons) and share it on stories, on the next story talk about any 1:1 openings you have
2- share a testimonial from a student inside one of your offers and then talk about what you teach inside the offer that gives students the outcome/result they’re looking for
3- share a series of stories highlight different offers that people can join of yours + what each offer is best for
4- share your story and how it lead you to what you do today plus what offer you created with your knowledge and experience from your journey
5- share a recent post from your feed to your stories and expand on the topic and then share how there are more conversations like this inside your offer

➡️Want to dive deeper into selling on stories? Join my Stories that Sell masterclass linked in my bio

The truth is…

I just wanted to use a caption hook to capture your attention😂🫶🏻

You know you’re a full blown entrepreneur when…

You’re obsessed with adding order bumps to checkout pages and seeing how much added income they bring in😂

Over the last few months I’ve added ORDER BUMPS (also known as upselling) to the checkout pages of many of my offers 

What it is?
At checkout people can add on an additional offer to their purchase, for an additional cost

Example: 
When you purchase List Building 101 ($97) you have the option to add on the Content Vault for an additional $25 

And guess what happens when you add an order bump to your offer? People add the additional offer onto their purchase which increase your average order value!

Now, not everyone adds on the order bump but many people do! Over the last few months I’ve been able to make $30,000 from order bumps alone 

Why are order bumps effective? People are already in buying mode so when you offer them another product at a low price it’s a no brainer for them to add it to their order!

What is the best strategy for order bumps? 1- You don’t have to discount your order bump offer but I’ve seen a lot of success in offering a discount if they add it on at checkout ($67 instead of $97 as an example)
2- Make sure that your order bump is something that makes sense for the customer to add onto their purchase (if you’re buying a business course you shouldn’t have a cookbook as your order bump)
3- You want the order bump to be a no-brainer add on so most of the time I recommend it being less than the cost of the main offer

➡️Try adding an order bump to one of your offers and watch your income increase!

The longer I do business and the more people I work with, the more I realize who I like working with the most because I am able to help them on the highest level— just because you CAN help someone doesn’t mean that you’re the best person to help them. 

Your business will evolve and change over time just like you evolve and change over time and that’s OKAY! Business is a journey, don’t forget to enjoy it🫶🏻
What has always been your thing? Let me know in the comments⬇️

My best tips below⬇️

1- Abandoned cart emails: this type of email (most of the time) can be set up inside of your checkout processor. It’s used to remind your customer to complete their purchase. I use kajabi checkout for most of my offers and there is an option to send an abandoned cart email 1, 6, 10, or 24 hours later. In this email you can give a discount as an incentive to buy or simply remind the customer that they’re missing out!

2- Welcome emails: a welcome email should be sent to new subscribers! I like to make this an introduction to me + my business and I have it automated to send after someone grabs one of my lead magnets

3- Lead magnet delivery emails: no need to make email marketing complicated, have an automated email set up to deliver your lead magnet to your subscriber so they have access to it within seconds of entering their info

4- Post purchase emails: this is my FAVORITE automated email and I’m about to share all of my best tips so don’t leave yet. A post purchase email gets sent after someone has purchased your offer. Inside of this email there are a few different things I like to include (sometimes I include all of these on one offer and sometimes I only include a few)

•a graphic that your customer can post to their stories and tag you to celebrate their purchase
•a link to the terms of use the customer agreed to at checkout
•any reminders or tips to get the most out of the offer
•dates, times, and links or any other information that is important to the offer
•a run down on your boundaries and how the customer can communicate with you (if at all)
•a link to login to their portal
•next steps they should take!

➡️Haven’t jumped on the email marketing train yet? No worries!! Tap the link in my bio and grab List Building 101 and get started building your email list today🥳

5 bonus CTAs⬇️

-Want more tips like these? Let me know in the comments
-Share this post with a friend who needs to hear ___ -Save this post and if it gets to 50 saves I’ll do ___
-Do you prefer ___ or ___? Let me know in the comments
-Have you ever experienced ___?

Just in case no one has told you lately, you’re doing great🫶🏻

Tag a friend who might need the reminder too!

More thoughts below⬇️

Create a welcome/start here highlight (or update it): this highlight should be an intro to who you are, what you do, and who you serve + I recommend sharing a few fun facts about yourself or your business

Create a testimonial highlight (or update it): this is one of the only highlights that doesn’t get outdated! Testimonials are great ways to build your credibility and sell your offers

Go through each highlight & delete any outdated information: usually I recommend deleting or recreating and reposting stories that are over 100 weeks old (unless it’s a testimonial then don’t) because your business grows so much and you’ve probably grown a lot as a content creator + your brand has probably changed too or at least been updated

Update your highlight covers to match your current branding: I like either curated pictures that match the content inside the highlight OR plain graphics but that’s just my personal opinion

Delete old or outdated highlight bubbles: if you haven’t posted to it in a while or referred someone to look at it, ask yourself if it’s necessary to keep up!

Create a highlight that is unique to your brand/biz: I have my “book” and “thoughts” highlight which are things that relate to my business but also aren’t just offers or tips!

Create a highlight for one of your offers: I personally recommend having at least 1 highlight for an offer but 3 is best! Choose your top 3 offers and use your highlights as a mini sales page for the offers 

Have a mix of text, picture, and video to keep your highlights engaging

Place your most important highlight first: I recommend your welcome/start here so people can connect with you and get to know your business 

Check to make sure any links shared are working and correct: as I was creating this reel I was going through my own highlights and saw 2 outdated links that were shared! Make sure your links are updated to lead where you want them to go and reflect your current price points!

➡️ if you loved this reel, than you will love IGU— an instagram growth membership for business owners! Tap the link in my bio to learn more🔥🔥🔥

10 more ideas below⬇️

1- mistake + how to fix/overcome it & plug your offer at the end

2- why your process works + what offer you teach that process in

3- client story/result/testimonial

4- showcase shocking before/after results 

5- what people think that need to do vs what they actually need need (without your offer vs join your offer and learn)

6- share 3 mistakes and how your offer will make sure that these and many more mistakes will be avoided + why that’s important

7- share an obstacle you overcome + how and then share the offer where you teach more about what you learned from the experience

8- share 3 reasons why (you should join ___ offer)

9- share a business evolution (or offer evolution), share different stages of business

10- share a piece of news and how it relates to what you teach inside of an offer

P.s— These are also great story ideas

I keep track of all of these insights PLUS several others in an excel spreadsheet and color code my top performing content so I can make sure that what I’m putting out is resonating and helping me to hit my goals (whatever they may be at the time)! I finally had some time to sit down and reflect on last month and wanted to share some take-aways

The biggest thing that I realized is that nothing happened overnight. Most of the things that made November a $150k month didn’t happen just in November or happen in November at all— it was months of building strategically + working on my mindset/energy that got me here. It was investments in a team (I have 5 people on my team), a coach, and other education + research and experimenting (oh and many failures too) that got me here. 

Reputation is built over time. Reoccurring revenue is built over time. An email list is built over time. Having a strategic offer suite is built over time. Building a team is built over time.

Good things take time. 

I didn’t jump from $1k months to $150k months in 1 month. I couldn’t imagine handling business if I did. 

There have been so many lessons that I’ve learned at every level as I’ve scaled my business month by month that have allowed for $100k+ months to become the norm and not just a random event that I can’t replicate. Every income level has taught me vital lessons that helped me get to 6-figure years and 6-figure months. 

I want to build something sustainable. Something repeatable. Something that doesn’t require me to be ON 24/7 in order to grow. Something that actually gives me freedom and I don’t have to pretend that I don’t work 24/7. Something disruptive. 

& because that’s been my focus— December is on track to be a $100k month

Bonus thoughts:
- I stopped trying to create the perfect feed and instead focused on creating valuable content
-i started creating my own unique reel audio
-more recently i shifted my focus from solely reels to reels + carousels equally
-i stayed in my own lane and stopped looking around to see what everyone else was/is doing on IG (this included unfollowing everyone in my niche)

Here’s a quick rundown on notes⬇️

While you most definitely don’t have to use them, and while I was 10000% against them when they first launched, I’ve seen some super creative uses for notes that boost business traffic AND I’ve gotten feedback from a few people that notes have helped increase their story views + content engagement

About notes:
-you have a maximum of 60 characters
-they appear as a bubble at the top of your DMs
-they disappear after 24 hours
-you can share notes with your Close Friends” list or to followers you follow back
-people can reply to notes via sending a direct message

Yes, notes can help create conversation in your DMs and drive traffic to your content, but I think that notes are going to be most beneficial for business growth ($$). Notes don’t affect your IG growth directly so if you don’t post them, no harm done.

I personally have been posting notes a few times a week. I have been sharing my notes to my close friend list (not followers who follow me back). I’ve been trying to look at it less as “something else I have to do” and more so as something that is fun that I can play around with

What are your thoughts on notes?⬇️

Something that’s cool about documenting

Well there’s a few things actually…

1- documenting helps you create content that has multiple layers to it. One layer could be education or inspiration (with the text on top), while the deeper layer is showing bts of your business which helps people connect to your brand

2- it’s easier to document than to create in my opinion. Just set up your camera & get a few clips! This type of content is always nice to have on hand because its easy to throw an audio in the background and text on top 

3- you can reuse these clips in many different ways (recap reels, transformation reels, progress reels, etc)

Not gonna lie…

My close friends list is probably my favorite space on instagram

I love providing value and sharing thoughts and opinions on my feed. I love sharing BTS and selling on stories. I love highlights. Okay you get it, I love a lot of things on IG😂

But something about the CF list just hits different. I don’t post on there daily. I don’t giveaway offers for free or run exclusive giveaways but I do share another level of realness on there that isn’t seen elsewhere on my social media

& the super cool thing about CF list (& really anything on IG if I’m being honest) is that you get to decide how you want to run things! 

Maybe your CF list is strictly for your current paying clients and you share updates about your offers in there

Or maybe your CF list is only for people who have showed interest in your offers but didn’t purchase and you share additional information about your offers

Or maybe your CF list is where you post monthly or weekly challenges for your community

It’s up to you how you want to use it but I highly recommend using it to connect with your community and share more about whatever you’re selling!

Why utilize the CF list for selling?
1- when people are on your CF list they feel special (cuz they are🫶🏻) and it puts you in a closer relationship with them because of it which leads to trust and trust leads to sales
2- you can connect with a smaller and more active part of your audience so you can create additional sales content to target them or just share different content with them depending on what you’re utilizing your CF list for and this can help you build the “favor return” buy (as I discussed in my last post)
3- you can sell MORE because people opted in to see more about your offers (if that’s what you choose to use your CF list for)
4- when people see bts it builds the know like and trust factor which helps you build a brand which helps you increase sales 

➡️want to learn more about how to utilize your stories to make more $$$? Check out my Stories that Sell masterclass linked in my bio!

More tips below⬇️

> track metrics like saves, non-follower reach, website clicks, and follows per post
> do a deep dive into accounts in my niche. Look at: what content performs well, what content formats they’re using, how often they’re posting, what writing style they have, what time of day they post, what hooks are successful, how they structure their content
> give without asking for 30 days— drop the “follow me for ___” CTAs and provide as much value as possible for free
> put the social in social media and take the time to connect with your audience: respond to DMs, reply to every comments, post interactive stories

Hope this helps!!🫶🏻🫶🏻🫶🏻

There are many things that play a role in the reels algorithm but there are some things that have more weight than others 

🚨One of those factors is WATCH TIME🚨

& I’m not just talking about getting a viewer to watch the first few seconds of your reel

Yes that’s important because if you don’t hook them then, you never will

But I’m also talking about engaging a viewer for long enough that they watch your ENTIRE reel & you get bonus points if you get them to watch the reel multiple times

So how do you do that? Here are a few ideas:

➡️use eye catching techniques— adding personality, transitions, angles, multiple clips, or simply the text (& colors) you use on screen

➡️use simplicity techniques— keep your reels short and sweet + clear and concise unless you have a really engaging topic. how do you know if it’s engaging? think about topics you get asked about all the time. Another example: 3-4 second reel with a hook and then “read the caption for more”

➡️use looping techniques— create a reel where the beginning and the end flow seamlessly together so people watch multiple times

➡️use curiosity techniques— make your followers look for something in the reel that they may have to watch your reel a few times to find (a hidden tip, emoji, etc) 

➡️use storytelling techniques— stories are one of the best ways to engage a viewer. Take them on a journey, hit on emotions

Challenge for the day: look at the reels in your saved folder and write down characteristics of them! Why? Because odds are high you watched them all the way through + multiple times and there is something that you can learn from those reels

Hold down on the screen to pause the reel🫶🏻

Best part of these ideas?? Most of these are just capitalizing off of things you’re already doing!!💸💸

Other ideas:
-UGC content for brands that you already use + love
-brand partnerships that fit your niche 
-monetization on social media platforms (reels bonus, subscriptions, etc)

Saw this hack on my FYP on TikTok a few months ago and it’s been a LIFESAVER (& storage saver😂) ever since! If you’re documenting you NEED this tip in your life

In this reel I created the “start” command but you’ll also want to create a “stop” command or you can just use the word “start” to start and stop the video (Creating the command for “stop” is exactly the same as creating the command for “start”)

Once you’ve saved the settings all you have to do is turn on & off voice control when documenting and then say “start” and “stop”

Samsung: go to your camera app>go to the settings in the top left>shooting methods>turn on voice commands (it’s said that you can’t turn off the video with this function though, only turn it on)

Android: you’ll need to download the “voice access” app and play around with the settings while in the camera app https://support.google.com/accessibility/android/answer/6151854?hl=en

Pixel: use Assistant to open up your camera app and then say “record a video”

1- Pinned content: make sure that your pinned content reflects the message + values you want to convey to your community. Don’t just pin the most viewed or engaged with content, create content with the intention of it being pinned. You have the opportunity to showcase your expertise, share your story (the deep one not the surface level one), and be the go-to expert in your niche. You have 7 seconds to win someone over— your pinned content is part of what people first see on your account so make it count

2- CTA in bio: do you even have a CTA in your bio?👀 make sure to update it to reflect the offers or freebies you want to highlight this year. Also update any dates that you may have in your bio like: “booking for 2023” 

3- FAQs in DMs: if you’re like me it’s easy to set things up and then forget about them but the new year is a great time to check back in and make sure that all the information is relevant and up to date. I recommend for your questions: 1. about a freebie 2. about your offer/service 

4- Highlights: especially your start here or welcome highlight! But making sure that you don’t have any broken or outdated links anywhere and that your highlights reflects your current branding and quality of content

Alright let’s dive into it…

(🚨WARNING: this is a whole training so buckle up)

& no this isn’t a generic, find your niche + identify your ideal follower, type of caption (though those 2 things are important)

Here’s the DEEP tea☕️

My growth on Instagram was stagnant for about 4 months up until a few weeks ago. After 1.5 years of constant growth, I hit a wall at the end of September. I was losing more followers than I was gaining some days and other days I would only gain 5-10 followers. 

I felt like I was doing EVERYTHING to grow, I was checking all the boxes, and was stumped on why it wasn’t happening (like I’m an IG coach for heavens sake, shouldn’t I of all people know what to do?!)

After several months of no growth, I decided to get out of my own way and really dig deep (not the surface level stuff)

Here’s 7 things I did + what I recommend for growth in 2023 for you too:

1- I got deep in the data: I whipped out the good ole excel spreadsheet and started tracking everything (non follower reach, hooks, content pillars, hashtags, etc). This helped me to see patterns in my content that I had missed, look at things from a new perspective, and really focus on data that drives me towards my goals. And YES this is different than just opening up IG and looking at your insights— tracking it this way really helps you to see what’s working + what’s not

⬇️Tips 2-7 in the comments⬇️

The reasons are…

There are no reasons!!

There are NO reasons why you shouldn’t create a series of content on your account

(a series of content means that you have multiple parts to it - part 1, part 2, etc)

I absolutely LOVE creating series because…

1- it makes for easy content. When you’re like “hmmm I have no idea what to post” you can always add to your series or start a new one. I’ve had my “instagram hacks I bet you didnt know part ___” series running for 2 years now and its been so fun to add to it. Note: your series doesn’t have to go on for that long, they can be short part 1/part 2 pieces of content too!

2- it makes your content bingeable! If you are 5 parts in and one part performs really well (viral) then people are going to want to watch parts 4,3,2 and 1 so they’re going to be searching your account and may come across other pieces of content of yours in the process that really resonate with them or are helpful!

3- they are fun!! Your series doesn’t have to be something serious. It could be a series of bloopers, a series of tips, a series of tools you love, a series of favorite podcasts/books! Get creative with it!

4- they create awesome guides because you can put all parts of the series in one place! See the tab next to my reels tab (the guide tab) on my profile for an example!

Let’s chat about live launches & recurring revenue⬇️

This is a BIG conversation that I’ve been having recently in my DMs as well as with my 1:1 clients

Example— Just this morning I had a DM from a business owner who was saying that he has very successful live launches a few times per year but then no one wants to buy outside of those launches and he wants to focus on having more consistent income on a month to month basis

Let me start off by saying, I have nothing against live launching or open/close enrollment for offers. Live launching can bring in great income & be great for certain businesses. I do this type of launching for my programs (scalability for example) and have done it for a few masterclasses as well. But I also have offers that I sell at all times (& build recurring revenue) which means that I don’t have to rely on just the success of live launches to bring in income

So what is my focus then? 

1- Having offers that I can sell ALL the time + offers that I live launch— selling all the time vs just during a live launch is totally different 

2- Building up my recurring revenue over time so I can have expected monthly income. Over the last year I’ve built my recurring revenue from $3k/month to $35k/month and having that predictable income is nice as an entrepreneur when things are so unpredictable. I personally would rather have this type of income rather than spikes of income from a live launch a few times a year BUT the combo of both is also great

I get it!

Because I used to do the exact same thing. I had no strategy for stories & focusing on my feed strategy, at the time, seemed way more important so I tried to utilize my stories to drive traffic back to my feed

Here’s the issue though…

Who wants to watch someone’s story that’s only reposts of feed content (& maybe a picture of their dog)? 

Not me🤷🏼‍♀️

Yes, people will watch your stories once or twice but you’re going to lose people after that because they’re going to know what to expect from your stories (which is not much)

So you start to see your story views drop, you panic and think that it’s because you’re posting too much on stories but in reality it’s just because your story content has no purpose or substance

My suggestion? 

1- spend 5 minutes looking through the top 3-5 story bubbles on your account (the ones you watch most) and take note of the content they share on stories
2- set a reminder on your phone 3-4x a day to take a picture of what you’re doing and share it on stories. Do this for 1 week
3- ask yourself with every story you post “what is the purpose of this story?”

Your stories are not just important for selling your offers, they’re also important for building trust and connection with your audience & building a brand. 

Note: it’s normal for there to be fluctuation in story views. On average a good story view count is around 5% of your total following

Note 2: there’s nothing wrong with reposting content on your stories (your own and other peoples), it’s when that type of content is ALL that you post on stories that people stop watching. People want to get to know you and your business not just see reposted content!

PASS OR SMASH SALES EDITION…

Here’s the thing, there’s a million ways to be successful and increase sales but the biggest thing at the end of the day is it needs to FEEL good to you

If it doesn’t feel good, pivot!

My thoughts on the 3 passes…

1- Run ads to drive sales:
Ads can be powerful but what I see often is people using ads as a band aid to the problem. They aren’t getting sales so they start running ads to get sales instead of digging deeper and finding the real issue. If you want to experiment with ads, I say wait until you can organically get sales first

2- Complex sales funnels + webinar streams:
What I teach is simplicity and I always will because complex 50 step funnels (the ones where you see a flow chart with 50 different pathways) aren’t necessary. Does this mean not have any funnels and systems? No. They are important for building a scalable business but they don’t have to be complex.

3- Cold DMs and pitching:
This one is simple. If I don’t like when people do it to me, why would I do it to others? Also, in my opinion, the days of bro-marketing are out. Relationship building is in. Does it take time to build a relationship? Yes. Is it worth it? Yes. 

So what do I recommend? Selling authentically by sharing your day to day life.

I think we often overcomplicate selling. It is a skill that can be learned and there is psychology and other aspects that are important to know but selling can be simple. 

You’re working on a clients project, talk about it and share the link for others to book. You’re creating a new offer, share a bts video and share a link for people to join the waitlist. Your program starts in 5 days, create a countdown and highlight 1 unique aspect of the program each day. 

When it comes to selling think LESS about how you can go out of your way to talk about your offer and make it flow & MORE about how you can share what’s already going on to lead into your offer with ease

Think about when you’re on the explore page on Instagram…

Ask yourself these 3 questions (and actually think about them, don’t just check a box):

1- What makes you click on a post to see more?
2- What makes you not click on a post?
3- What makes you stay on the post after clicking?

For me, the hook is what draws me in but there are also many hooks that don’t draw attention

But why is the hook so important?

When someone clicks on your content, spends time on it, and engages with it— it tells the algorithm that people like it. The algorithm then pushes it out to more people so your reach increases and if you have a large amount of people doing this your post will also end up on the explore page. So clicks=reach. Less clicks=less reach. And since your hook is the first thing people see, it has a BIG job in getting people to stick around

So what makes a catchy hook?

In my opinion a catchy hook is short (not like the hook I used in post 1), it leaves a bit of mystery as to what I’ll get when I click but also enough info that I know what I’m getting into, and it’s not the same generic hook that everyone uses (“how to __”). Numbers also work great and having BIG text that stands out vs small text that is hard to read!

Challenge of the day: take a look at the hooks on your 3 most recent posts and analyze them! Could they be improved? More concise? More unique?

1, 2, or 3???

The lie is number 3!

The algorithm doesn’t look at if you’re posting from drafts or uploading it from your camera roll or filming in app and posting it immediately

So what are the most important factors in the reels algorithm?

According to Instagram…
“The most important predictions we make are how likely you are to watch a reel all the way through, like it, say it was entertaining or funny, and go to the audio page (a proxy for whether or not you might be inspired to make your own reel.)”

Instagram also avoids recommending reels that:
•are watermarked or low resolution
•are muted or contain borders
•are majority text
•are focused on political issues 

& while there is no “beating the algorithm” or “hacking the algorithm” knowing these things can help you to know what to focus on and what to look for as you analyze your content

Two more factors to consider:

Engagement-
One of the biggest factors the algorithm takes into account when deciding if it will show it to new eyes (non followers) is the engagement of your current audience. If your engagement is low it tells the algorithm that your audience doesn’t like your content and it’s less likely to show it to new eyes. This doesn’t mean that you cant increase engagement over time through different strategies but know that low engagement can be a factor of slow to no growth

An old account-
I want to share my story when it comes to growing an account. I hear often that if you have an old account it’s hard to grow (this can be true in some cases if there are other factors involved) but that hasn’t been my experience. My account was started in 2012 and I’ve been able to grow it by hundreds of thousands of followers

10 income streams⬇️

1- Membership: $30,000-$40,000/month
IG University has a monthly, 6 month, and yearly subscription

2- Programs: $10,000-40,000/month
These are live trainings that I run and they are usually 2-4 weeks long

3- Coaching: $20,000-$30,000/month
I take on 3-5 1:1 coaching clients per month but I also have group coaching (miniminds) 

4- Masterclasses: $5,000-10,000/month
This income comes from launching new masterclasses and selling the recording of past masterclasses

5- Courses: $2,000-5,000/month
I have 2 courses ($247 and $97) that I mainly use as order bumps on other offers

6- Brand Partnerships: $1,500/month
I don’t do a lot of brand work but I usually work with 1 brand a month on one of my social media platforms (usually TikTok or Pinterest) and sometimes through email marketing

7- Affiliate Marketing: $500-1,000/month
The main income comes from sharing my Flodesk and Flipstik affiliate link but I also have an Amazon storefront

8- Social Media Bonuses: $200-1,000/month
This comes from Instagram bonuses or Pinterest bonuses (Pinterest creator program is no longer a thing though)

9- E-products: $500/month
I sell a few eproducts mainly as bonuses or order bumps on my main offers

10- Event/team trainings: $1,000/month
Once a month I usually do a guest training for another business, an event, or teams. 

My biggest piece of advice? Start with one income stream and then create more over time (you don’t need 10 income streams to get started) & then as your business grows you won’t have to rely on just 1 income stream to hit your goals!

BIG ANNOUNCEMENT at the end of the caption🚨

Let’s try this again😂 thank you IG for deleting only some of my text after posting (if you’re struggling with this, save the reel with text and then reupload it to IG). Okay now for the tea on CTAs…

Something I see often on people’s content is the same CTA over and over and over again— usually it’s about their offer and tapping the link in their bio and it’s a copy and pasted CTA that’s on pretty much every post

While that is better than having no CTA at all, what I’ve come to learn is that different audiences respond differently to different CTAs so if you’re only using 1 you could be missing out 

For example— if I left a “tag a friend in the comments” CTA on my content, not many people would tag a friend (some would but not may). But if I leave the “drop a ❤️ in the comments and I’ll DM you a link to __” my comments are filled with ❤️’s

But I know many people who use the “tag a friend CTA” and their comments are filled with tags. It really depends on your audience

Which means that testing your CTAs is so important! 

On reels it’s harder to see direct results of a CTA unless we have a CTA that encourages people to take action by commenting but on picture content we can look at the insights and see website taps which is really helpful when it comes to seeing if the CTA was effective in driving traffic to your website! 

Use these creative CTAs to test and find what works best for your account! 

CTA= call to action statement

I feel ya… it’s scary 

But guess what? You run a BUSINESS! 

& in order for a business to make $$$ there need to be sales and in order for there to be sales people need to know that you have offers which means… you need to talk about your offers! 

If you have a hobby, great, don’t talk about your offers. But my guess is that if you’re reading this, you’re wanting to build a money and impact making machine

Think of it like this— the way you keep the neon “OPEN” sign on for your business is by talking about your offers! If you looked at your business rn with that in mind, is the “OPEN” sign on or off?

Here are 6 ways to talk about your offer today:

1- at the end of your carousel posts, share a slide that talks about your offers! Include a visual, the title, the tagline, and a short rundown of why the offer is great + how to purchase it

2- share a testimonial on your stories and give more background knowledge around how the client got to that point— what offers(s) did they join? Where were they previous to the offer? Pain points?

3- share an obstacle you overcame + a small lesson on how and what offer you teach more that information in more depth

4- share an unpopular opinion that you have about your industry then share what offer you dive deeper into those beliefs & why it’s important + for who

5- post two question boxes on stories. 1- “if you’ve purchased (insert offer), what did you love most about it?” 2- “if you haven’t purchased (insert offer), what’s holding you back from buying?” Share those responses on stories!

6- go live and talk about an upcoming offer and give an exclusive and limited time bonus for people who join

>Now it’s time to implement! Do one of the above, or talk about your offer in a different way and then comment “DONE” when you’re done!! Let’s get those open signs ON for your biz today!

Alrighty, let me be completely honest with you…

I’ve received more troll messages in the last 2 months than I ever have on my journey thus far

I was asked the other day on a podcast interview how I navigate all the troll messages and my response is “it’s been tough.”

It’s easy to say “hurt people hurt people” or “they’re just jealous” but when you’re in the thick of it… let’s just call it how it is… it sucks

If you go look at my reels you’ll see that many of the comments are still on the posts but I’ve also blocked and deleted many

What I’ve been learning when it comes to trolls is that…

•to protect your energy sometimes you need to block and delete — on average I block 50 accounts a day. Protecting your energy as a business owner is so key because that energy doesn’t just effect you, it also effects how you show up for your customers and clients 

•knowing your WHY is extremely important. And I’m not talking the basic “I’m an entrepreneur because I want to have time freedom.” I’m talking about the deep deep deep WHY, the kind that keeps you planted when times get tough. The kind that keeps you dedicated when you don’t feel like doing anything. The kind that gets you going in the morning. It’s more than just “making an impact”, it’s more than just “making money”. Spend the time getting DEEP

•sometimes you just need a good cry

•if you’re going to respond (you most definitely don’t need to), catch them with kindness. I’ve been responding to several troll messages with “thank you!!” lately and I can only imagine the look on their face when they see my kind response to their nasty message

•& lastly, you should lean on your community— I posted on my stories the other day about the trolls, just having an honest conversation, and my community swooped in and backed me up with many of the troll comments and honestly it was so powerful and had me crying joyful tears all day (you know who you are, thank you🫶🏻). Your people are there to support you even if it seems like all there is is hate, your community is grateful for you!

I’ll leave you with this— if you’re in the thick of it right now, I’m sending you love and I hope you know that you’re not alone❤️

CONVERT VIEWERS > FOLLOWERS

Are your viewers tapping into your account and immediately running away?!

There are MANY reasons why your account and content might not be converting but here are the 5 things I would look at:

1️⃣ meet your followers where they are at— simplify your messaging and make sure you know the part of the journey that your ideal follower is at right now, what they are struggling with, + how they are experiencing their pain point and speak to that. If you’re not doing that, they’re probably thinking, “wow this is great but this account is not for me”

2️⃣ utilize storytelling— if your viewers aren’t converting into followers they may not be connecting with you. Tell their story (meet them where they’re at) but also tell your story + hit on emotions. What does your ideal follower want? What do they desire? Use that to paint a picture through storytelling

3️⃣ brand yourself— if you’re not standing out, you’re fitting in. If you look like everyone else and act like everyone else then why would someone follow you when they already follow other accounts just like yours? & stop thinking you’ve branded yourself just because you use the same fonts and colors— it’s deeper than that. share what makes you tick, share your opinions, thoughts, hopes, dreams, journey!

4️⃣ you’re not giving them a reason to stick around— if your content isn’t quality, if your bio isn’t clear on the WHO, WHAT, and WHY, and if you don’t have a binge worthy feed people aren’t going to stick around

5️⃣ you haven’t posted enough or consistently enough— yes, a good content base is important to turn viewers into followers because it proves that you’re in this for the long run and you’re not gonna ditch them in a week or two. + it provides credibility and gives people content to binge

🛑Stop overlooking these 5 thing just because they seem simple— these are mistakes I see EVERY SINGLE DAY.

I get asked often what to look at if an offer didn’t sell well (or at all) during a launch

Before I jump in I just have to say this: I am proud of you!!! Even if you sold 0 offers during your launch you did something that most people aren’t brave enough to do… put yourself out there and take action! Creating and selling an offer is no easy feat so give yourself a big hug🤍

Okay now for what you’re really here for…

While there’s a BUNCH of different things that can contribute to failed launches, here are the top 5 most common issues I see:

1- your messaging (marketing) doesn’t reflect the value of your offer: is the outcome clear for someone who goes through your offer? Did you just list the features, benefit, and price and not utilize storytelling? Did you market the offer or the solution the offer provides? 

2- there’s no unique selling point: how does your offer different from other offers on the market? Do you teach a different technique/method? What is the background/knowledge that you bring to the offer?

3- there wasn’t a strategic launch: I’m sorry but posting on stories and sending out an email that you have a new offer you’re selling isn’t a launch strategy. A launch strategy should not only bring in sales but create offer awareness. A launch should also warm your audience up to your offer— launching starts way before selling the offer ever begins

2- Course: prerecorded training— everything is done before you sell the offer

Let’s talk about why—

When someone adds you to their favorites list your content will show up on their favorites feed AND higher in their home feed (the default IG feed)

As you scroll through your home feed, if you’ve added someone to your favorites feed you’ll see an orange star at the top right corner of the post

But how does this relate to increased engagement you might ask?

It’s simple

When your content is seen more (because it’s at the top of your communities feed), it’s more likely to be interacted with hence increasing your engagement

(This is especially important if you feel like your community isn’t seeing your content)

The content at the top of someone’s feed is more likely to be seen (& engaged with) then content 20 posts down 

Same concept applies on google— 75% of people, when searching, never go to the second page of search results. If your business is on the second page, it doesn’t mean you’ll never be seen it’s just a lot less likely. If your business is at the top, you’re way more likely to be seen

And if this hasn’t convinced you enough… let’s talk about another reason why favorites is amazing— with the way the algorithm works, the quicker you get engagement for your community (& the more you get) the more likely the algorithm is to show your content to others

So having people add you to their favorites feed isn’t just helpful for getting your community to see your content but also NEW people to see your content as well!

With all that being said (can you guess what this CTA is going to be?😂)…

Yes, you may have made $10k/month by posting more but can you scale to $25k/month SUSTAINABLY doing the same thing? Or $50k/month? Or $100k/month?

Sustainability is KEY and even though I see this word all of Instagram, a lot of the strategies I see being taught are often not sustainable (in my opinion)

If you have a team of people creating content and posting for you then you might be able to sustain a high volume of content (or if you’re an IG expert like me where part of my job is literally to post on IG) 

So yes, the sales might be nice by increasing your posting to daily but building a business where you have to be on 24/7 isn’t the goal (or at least that’s not my goal)

If posting daily is sustainable for you, great. If it’s not sustainable for you, that’s great too. I just want you to know that you don’t HAVE to post daily in order to grow

Other things to consider are:
-are you creating content for other platforms or just Instagram? If you are creating for just instagram it may make sense to post daily but if you’re also doing email marketing, pinterest, podcasting, etc. it might not make sense
-there are more ways than just posting on Instagram daily to help you stay top of mind and relevant
-do your sales rely on you posting daily? if so, I would take a look at your business structure
-do you really NEED more followers or do you just need to better nurture the ones you already have?
-are you in this for the long run or just to make a quick buck and then you burn your business to the ground because it wasn’t built in a way that aligns with the life you want to live? Instagram growth, no matter how much you post, is a long term game so go into choosing your posting frequency with that mindset

Here’s the thing—

I am not “above” doing any of these things nor do I think that people who do these things won’t be successful

I just personally don’t do them

There are many ways to run a business and these are all things I’ve stood behind since day 1 of my business (not just since growing my business to multiple 6 figures)

Buckle up for all my thoughts (cuz you already know I’m gonna give you allllll the tea):

Discovery calls—
I treat my instagram account like a discovery call (do you treat yours like one?). This means that I let people get to know me through my content— the real me not the fake instagram me. My voice, my flaws, my triumphs, my opinions (like this reel), my failures. I share my pricing upfront so there’s transparency & I share testimonials for social proof so there’s confidence when people buy. I also use different methods like applications, for example, to vet people for my higher ticket offers vs a discovery call

Follow up messages—
I believe that the customer will purchase if it’s the right fit for them and I’m here if they have any questions along the way. I will ALWAYS answer questions because I believe in making educated decisions

Paid ads—
I’ve done over $1 million in sales with 0 paid ads
I’ve sold out of 1:1 coaching for months in advance with 0 paid ads
I’ve taken days off and even weeks off of work and still brought in 5+ figures with 0 paid ads
When you focus on your audience and nurturing relationships, that’s when the magic starts to happen. That being said, I want to start playing around with ads in my business just for fun to see if I can find an aligned way to run them! 

Sent cold pitch DMs—
Sometimes I’m like, “do I really even need to address this??” And then I check my DMs and they’re FILLLLEEDDDDD with cold pitch messages and I’m like yup, let’s talk about it. I’m just gonna be blunt — cold pitch messages are ick and they’re outdated. Consumers want connection, cold pitch messages don’t give them that. It’s that simple.

Disclaimer: not all testimonials/reviews will have context that you can share and that’s totally okay! The goal is simply to share more context when possible

To get more context, look at the questions you’re asking on your testimonials forms OR when someone sends you a testimonial, simply ask them to share more about their journey with you!

>This one simple shift will not just help you create & share better testimonials, it will also increase your engagement on posts where testimonials are shared because they become more engaging content when context is added!

Examples of how this works in multiple niches:
>if you’re a fitness coach instead of just posting a before and after picture of a client, share the before and after picture and then share the time between pictures and what program of yours that they joined
>if you’re a Pinterest manager instead of just sharing screenshots of increase website clicks and pin saves, share the niche of the client you’re working with, how often you’re pinning content for them, and how long you’ve been working with them (notice how you have all of this information at your finger tips already??)
>if you’re a sleep consultant for babies instead of just sharing that your clients babies are sleeping through the night, walk people through the offer they joined + when, what struggles they had before joining, and where they’re at now

One of my most asked questions recently goes something like this — “my content isn’t reaching any new eyes as of lately, how can I reach more non followers?”

Let me just start off by saying that there are no “hacks” for reaching non followers & the BEST thing you can do is pay attention to your analytics

But because I always give you all the deets, let’s breakdown what really works:

1- Post reels to just the reels tab (not to your feed): I don’t recommend posting all reels here but when you post reels to only the reels tab you oftentimes will reach more non followers. This doesn’t always mean though that those non followers will convert into followers so you need to make sure that the content you post to just the reels tab is EXTRA good because it’s being mainly seen by brand new people who don’t know you yet.

2- Create shareable content: yes, I know what you’re thinking… “this is such a general tip” but when was the last time you focused on creating shareable content and not just content that will “perform well”? I encourage you to look at your analytics & find past content that was shared the most and repurpose it AND look at the content you are sharing of others and ask yourself why

3- Get on the explore page: there are many pieces to this, a whole lesson worth actually, but a big part of getting on the explore page is people sharing & saving your content and the other key piece is how quickly your community interacts with the content after you post it 

4- Collaborate with other accounts: this is a sure way to reach new people because you’re pooling together 2 audiences 

5- Take the time to connect with your current community: when you take care of your people they’ll take care of you (by sharing and interacting with your account)

6- Get people to add you to their favorites feed: I talked about this 2 reels back

7- Create unique content: this is also a whole lessons worth by itself but let me just say that the “5 tips” and “how tos” aren’t going to cut it in helping you reach new people. You need to get outside of the box

This has been on my mind a lot lately…

First off I just want to define what I mean by an income dip because I’m not talking about going from $10k to $0 every other month — with your income being alllll over the place. 

I see an income dip as a lower income month(s) in your business in comparison to YOUR monthly average

For example, you might have had a $5k month in January, a $2k month in February, a $4.8k month in March, & a $4.5k month in April. February being the income dip.

It’s important to talk about what an income dip is because like I said above, I’m not referring to your income being all over the place — that to me says that your business lacks the structure and strategy to sustain higher (or simply consistent) income months

I’m talking about the normal ups and downs that all business owners experience 

Why should we normalize income dips?
1- you might be experiencing an income dip because you’re pivoting your business model, pricing, boundaries, offers, etc. to be more sustainable and have more consistency in 

2- there is SO MUCH to be learned from an income dip like staying power for example. What you do during an income dip is more important, in my opinion, than what you do when business is good (& at a high)

3- you can have a very healthy and successful business and experience income dips. Ups and downs are normal. There are “slow seasons” in every business — this doesn’t mean you cant still be highly successful in those months and be above average but also know that as a business owner your business is dependent on consumer behavior and consumer behavior changes throughout the year!

4- you might have a business structure that runs on live launches that take place a few times per year. Which means you might have a $30k month during a launch and then a $5k month on non launch months. There’s nothing wrong with this type of income dip because it’s strategic based on the way you launch/sell

Alright, let’s break this down…

I wanted to share these tips because b-roll type of content (content that captures your everyday life like this reel) is a very popular trend for content creation this year

& if you’re creating this type of content you want to make sure that your videos are clear & crisp so they perform well AND, here’s a fun fact, because people relate the quality of your content to the quality of your offers/services so quality is KEY!

Here are my BEST tips for clear reels:

1- make sure you upload your reel using good wifi/service 

2- if you’re taking the video on your phone camera (not inside the IG app) make sure your camera settings are at 1080p 30fps or 4k at 30fps. Only shoot at 4k if your setting is on “most compatible” (see point 4). Instagram doesn’t support frame rates higher than 30fps as of rn

3- wipe off your camera lens before taking the video (simple but often forgotten)

4- if you have an iPhone switch from “high efficiency” to “most compatible”. This capture your videos in JPEG/H.264 which is best for instagram. The file format is important because MP4 with the H.264 codec is best!

5- if you don’t want to worry about your settings, take the video inside the instagram app!

6- back facing camera is higher quality than your front facing camera but if you have good lighting then you can take great video with your front facing camera as well 

7- there are filters you can apply to your reel that can sharpen your video (you can search for those under effects. Ex: 4k)

8- turn on “high quality uploads” in your settings on instagram (settings>account>data usage>high quality uploads) OR when you go to post your reel go to advanced settings>upload at highest quality

9- film your videos with GOOD bright lighting (natural is best)! If the lighting is bad it’ll effect the quality of the video

Totally had a different plan for todays reel but as I was scrolling through all of my B-roll content to find the perfect video for the tips I wanted to share I got sucked into looking at videos of my journey and couldn’t help but piece this reel together

It’s been quite the journey. 

While I started what I currently do in august of 2021, my journey really started in December of 2019 with network marketing

Network marketing played a pivotal role in getting me to where I am today and it also led to opportunities like doing social media management for a large influencer, working as head of social media for a start up company, and training teams of hundreds of women worldwide

Each opportunity along my path has led me to where I am today and I know that each “yes” gave me the skills and knowledge that has helped me to build an empire on social media

The journey hasn’t always been easy. 

There have been many failures and tears shed along the way but it’s also been the best thing I’ve ever done

If I can share one thing that I’ve learned from my journey it’s this—

NEVER STOP DREAMING.

Everything you want is possible + so so so much more 

>>>If you want to hear the full in-depth version of my journey, type in “Radical Disruption” into your podcast streaming platform and listen on episode 1! (Or tap on my podcast highlight)

I don’t say this to discourage, it’s just the simple reality of social media

But also, it’s not just how social media rolls. It’s how most things roll.

The movies 1 year ago that were the trendiest aren’t the same as the popular movies today. The best sales tactics 3 years ago are different than the best sales tactics today. The most fashionable outfits are different today than they were 3 years ago. The coolest music today isn’t the same as the coolest music last year. 

The truth is, as consumers we get tired of things and look for the “new”

It’s the exact same on instagram. It doesn’t mean your content strategy didn’t work in the past. It doesn’t mean your content isn’t quality. Things simply come and go 

It doesn’t mean your information needs to change (most likely), just the way you deliver it

If you don’t want to get left behind, you have to evolve

Note: something I want to make clear is that “keeping up” doesn’t mean you have to jump on every trendy thing happening. There are larger trends that happen in the content creation space that last longer (oftentimes 6-12 months) and there are bigger changes the happen in the algorithm multiple times a year that should be focused on. So no this isn’t about chasing the trends, it’s about building a solid content strategy but leaving room for when changes take place a few times a year to evolve as consumer habits evolve

Note 2: think about your own consumer habits — what content were you saving the most 1 year ago vs what content are you saving the most now? Don’t just think content formats, really think about what’s inside of that content. Example: I was saving a bunch of transition reels and now I’m saving a bunch of b-roll reels

This isn’t the optimal strategy for growth but this is one I recommend if you have a busy schedule but still want to show up on IG and grow!

1- Post 2 reels & 1 carousel a week:
Having content variety is important and beneficial — focus on creating sharable content with your carousel 

Remember though that you get out what you put in. If you’re looking to take your business full time and rely on IG for leads and sales but only post 1x a week, it’s going to take you a while to hit your goal. Your actions should match your goals

2- Repurpose 1 post per week:
Repurpose NOT repost — look at top performing pieces of content from 3-4 months ago and repurpose them into new pieces of content. 

For example, this reel was a well performing carousel post that I shared about a year ago and now I’ve turned it into a reel

3- Create engagement days:
Each day of the week you do a different type of engagement for 5-15 minutes

Example: Mon - respond to all unanswered comments on your recent post(s). Tues — respond to DMs. Wed — interact with content on your feed of accounts you follow. Etc

4- Batch all of your content:
Stories: Once a week (not all stories can be batched but sales stories or even some BTS can be!)
Reels: Every 2 weeks
Carousel/Feed posts: 1x a month

5- Schedule posts:
This is the ONLY time I am pro-scheduling. If you have the time to post manually and engage with your community before/after posting I highly recommend it even if it’s only for 3 minutes. BUT if you can’t post manually, scheduling is better than not posting — I recommend using the in-app scheduling feature on IG

Now let this be clear —

I am NOT sharing this post to say that all of your offers have to be thousands of dollars or even the “top” offer in the market in order for you to be successful 

The cool part is that you can make money either way. You can make money selling the $0.25 water bottle at Costco and you can make money selling the $5 water bottle on the airplane (both are actually needed). You can make money selling $40k coaching calls and you can make money selling $1500 coaching calls (or even $100 calls)

The goal of this post is to really push you to think about HOW you are positioned in the market and how that effects what you can charge for your offers + how your business is perceived

Questions to ask:
•when people think about my account, what do they think about?
•how am I showcasing my expertise and setting myself and my business apart from others in the market
•do I want to increase my prices on my offers? And if so, can I shift my positioning (if needed) to make sure that there is still value in my offers even with a price increase?
•am I seen as an authority in my space? If not, how can I change that?
•do I have my own unique strategies, framework, and techniques that I can share that will help me stand out?

Note: I gave the example of coaching in this post but this concept doesn’t just apply with 1:1 or group coaching — this applies to every industry and niche. If you’re a hairstylist, if you’re a heart surgeon, if you’re a graphic designer, if you’re a makeup artist, if you’re an architect, etc. it’s applicable.

Here’s the thing—

I am not against paid ads at all

Let’s break it down further ↓

First off I just want to say that this isn’t a random list thrown together for kicks and giggles. This is a list of things I see DAILY on instagram with accounts who are struggling to convert viewers → followers

& yes, I do spend time looking at accounts daily, doing audits, giving feedback and more!

Okay, now to dive in…

→ you’ve built 0 connection with viewers
Put simply, there is no emotional connection created through your content. They don’t know your story or journey. They don’t know YOU. 

→ your content sends one message & your bio sends another
They see a piece of your content, maybe on their explore page, and they’re interested and then they tap into your account and your bio and highlights give off a different vibe or niche causing confusion & confused viewers don’t hit “follow”. Confusion can happen due to lack of clarity, using words that don’t make sense to the viewer, and not giving enough information 

→ you’re not giving people a reason to stick around
No sugar coating things around here… your content is like everyone else’s in your niche so you don’t stand out and people don’t care to stick around because they already follow 5 other accounts just like yours. What makes your account unique? Do you have different values or perspectives? Do you present information in a different way?

→ you’re not passing the 7 second test
The truth is, aesthetics do matter. Branding does matter. High quality images do matter. You only have a few seconds to make a good first impression & on top of that, people relate the quality of your content/account to the quality of your offers/services so it’s important to think about your image

→ you’re not showing up as an authority & leader
You might have great content, great branding, and show up consistently but you don’t stand out and stand up as an expert in your niche. This starts with speaking boldly, sharing wins, getting vulnerable, voicing your opinions, and taking the time to really connect with your community. Think about who you see as an authority (in any niche) and why you see them as an authority

Whether it’s college or corporate or entrepreneurship or stay at home mom or trade school, I hope you you’re doing something you love

& I hope that even if you are doing something that you love that you stay open to new opportunities in case you come across something that you love more (because that’s how my journey has been)

In Dec 2019 I started a network marketing business to help pay for nursing school

In Aug 2020 I dropped out nursing school to take my network marketing business full time after realizing that building an online business was something I was passionate about

In Aug 2021 after a crazy turn of events, after posting 120+ times on Instagram and growing my own following, I decided to start my own business and teach others how to grow their following on Instagram 

In January 2022 I hit 100k followers on Instagram and soon after hired my first employee (today I have 5 total) + launched my signature offer

In March 2023 I hit $1 million in revenue (exactly 1.5 years after starting my business) after a bunch of failures + daily consistency — no overnight success story here 

It’s crazy what can happen in just a few years when you decide to follow your dreams and block out the haters

I should’ve titled this reel “under-rated IG growth tips” because it’s a seriously under-rated tip that is so powerful

Studying your own consumer habits around content consumption alone isn’t going to help your grow but when you study your habits and then implement what you learn, that’s when the magic happens

I spent some time studying my own consumer habits just this morning and it shifted the way I presented this topic in this reel (I changed my hook and started a new IG series)

Here are 10 questions to ask yourself when consuming content or just simply scrolling on IG… 

1- Who’s content do I like consuming the most + why?
2- When I swipe past a reel, post, or story what makes me do that?
3- When I watch a whole story set or reel all the way through, what kept me engaged?
4- What hooks, if any, draw me in?
5- When I’m on the explore page, which posts do I tap into and why?
6- With carousel posts, what keeps me reading the whole post vs tapping out? How is the information presented?
7- What length of reels do I normally watch start to finish? What type of reels do I watch the most?
8- What content stands out and gets me to save or share?
9- What do I look at on an account before hitting the “follow” button? + what stops me from hitting the “follow” button?
10- Are there certain colors or fonts that attract more than others?

The more you think about/learn how you consume, the more knowledge you’ll have to take and implement & see results on your IG account

If you’re new around here (hi!!!!!), selling on IG stories is one of my most favorite topics

On an average month about 70-80% of my revenue comes from selling on stories so it’s a tool I use heavily in my business & I want to help you utilize it too!

Here are 5 ways that you can sell on stories TODAY—

1- Screenshot a DM question about an offer and answer it on stories
>If you can’t find any questions about your offers in your DMs look at your comment section and your emails! This is such a great way to answer a question that others probably have as well + showcase that people are interested in your offer(s) which will get others intrigued

2- Share a before/after that relates to your offer & share your offer 
>this could be a before/after picture if that makes sense for your niche but it could also be something that isn’t screenshotable (yes that’s a word according to the Mya Nichol dictionary) like a mindset shift, a feeling a client may have, routines, etc. You can collect those in testimonial forms

3- Tell the story behind how the offer came about
>there is always a reason behind each offer so share WHY you created it! This will help people see more of the BTS and the storytelling will help them feel more connected to the offer

4- Compile 2-3 client case studies & use those to showcase your offer’s success
>testimonials are good but case studies are the best because they really help people to put themselves in your clients shoes and picture themselves getting the same results. Because instead of just sharing a win you’re sharing the journey it took to get there which is much more relatable 

5- Share a BTS look of your offer
>if you use kajabi, for example, you can take a video of the modules + bonuses inside to help people get a feel for what it would be like to be inside the offer

Honesty hour…

Growth on instagram has been slow and engagement has been wayyy down the last few weeks for me (can you relate? Let me know in the comments)

But I’m truly not concerned & here’s why…

1- I know that it’s normal for there to be ups and downs on instagram and just because I’m in a downtime right now, doesn’t mean it’ll be like this forever. Yes, it sucks don’t get me wrong but I’m not worried & also know that there are some factors that are out of my control when it comes to reach

2- In order to continue to grow my business, make sales, and increase my income I can focus on serving and selling to my current audience vs only focusing on getting new eyes on my account — I saw something the other day that said, “You don’t need more followers you need better marketing” and I couldn’t agree more. Even with 1000 followers you can make sales!

3- I trust in the places I’ve built my business. I haven’t just built my business on instagram, I’ve also focused on email marketing, putting my name and links in other places by being a guest speaker in other peoples offers and on podcasts, and more. Don’t throw all of your eggs in one basket, make sure to build your business on places that don’t have algorithms (like an email list or having a website that ranks well on search engines)

How can you prepare now to have a thriving business even in the downtimes? Your challenge for today is to answer that question!

The reality is, most people overcomplicate making more $$. The solution you’re looking for is really simple. 

If you’re not hitting your income goals or you want to increase your revenue you need to look at one (or maybe a few) of these 7 points. & yes these apply to lack of revenue just as much as it does increasing revenue

Once you identify the problem you can then reverse engineer the solution 

Example 1:
I have a great offer that I sell and market well but I need more leads in order to hit my income goals

If I want to make $1,000 and I have a product that is $127 then I need to make 8 sales.

In order to make 8 sales then statistically (with a sales conversation rate being ~8%) I need to be in front of 100 people who are good leads

Now my focus is increasing visibility to increase my leads

Example 2:
I have offers that are selling well but I want to make more from promoting what I already have

If I have an offer that is $247 and I sell an average of 25 per month = $6175. I can add an upsell for $67 to the offer which on average will bring in around $200 more per month

If I have another offer that is $67 and I sell an average of 50 per month = $3350. I can add an upsell for $47 to the offer which on average will bring in around $235 more per month

So now my income is an extra $435 per month which is an extra $5220 per year

Now my focus is getting more strategic with upsells/downsells

Winning Formula for using Chat GPT ↓

Step 1- give background on who you are, what you do, and who you help (ideal follower). think niche statement here + ideal follower
Step 2- share what you want chat gpt to write for you (ex: caption, carousel post, email, etc)
Step 3- share the tone that you want chat gpt to write in (ex: conversational, professional, funny, etc)
Step 4- breakdown what you want the content to look like. outline the structure and how you want it created (ex: eye catching hook as the title followed by 7 pages of headlines with paragraphs underneath. ending with a call to action prompting viewers to check out:____)
Step 5- share the prompt for the content (ex: what are the 5 things every new account on Instagram should do to grow?)

Let me know in the comments if you want to see more content on chat GPT 

Note: chat GPT gives a good starting place/outline but especially for things like posts, captions, and bullet point or listed information you should use it as a starting place and not a copy and paste message. For things like keywords and hashtags you can definitely copy and paste (after reading through) because those things don’t need your knowledge, expertise, or background like posts and captions do. Plus you know your community and ideal audience best at the end of the day, not a computer system

To sum it all up— it’s a great tool for many things but if you’re looking to build a unique and stand out brand your stories, voice, experiences, and connection to your community are going to help you do that. NOT an automated system. Chat GPT should be used as a companion tool, not the solution for all content creation🫶🏻

You have 6 pieces of content that can be pinned (3 on feed, 3 on reels tab) so you can have each piece answer 1 of these questions or you may have one piece that answers multiple of these questions!

Note: these questions don’t need to be directly answered in a post. Like you don’t need to say “this is the type of content you can expect to see” — instead use the pinned content as examples of what people can expect to see

1- what is your story + background?
Share how you got to where you are today, why you started your business, and even goals you hope to achieve 

2- what type of content can people expect to see on your account?
This isn’t just topics that you cover (think about hitting on content pillars here) but also the format (carousel, reel, talking reel, tutorial based reel, live videos, picture, etc)

3- what unique perspective do you offer the industry (aka what makes your account different)?
Share beliefs, opinions, things you agree/disagree with, things to avoid + why, etc

4- what should people do next?
You can use CTAs on the pinned content (caption or end of the post) to guide people to next steps. Such as getting signed up for your email list, checking out your offers, or simply commenting and sharing more about themselves 

5- is there something people can implement in their life immediately?
Make sure that at least 1 of your pinned posts is tangible, something that people can implement and see results from — you want to give them a mini win

So many accounts aren’t using pinned content or aren’t using them strategically! This is prime real estate to take advantage of on your account!

How to find your best posting time↓

1- Open your insights and look for the most active hours each day

2- Ask your audience using a poll in stories when they are most active on Instagram — if your story views aren’t great you can try using a CTA on a post to ask when people are most active

3- Experiment! Test out posting at different times and look at the differences in engagement within the first few minutes and long term as well.

4- Study your audience — really think about what your audience’s habits are. If they are moms, when are they going to check IG? If they work a 9-5, when are they going to check IG? If they are med school students, when are they going to check IG? Take the time to get to know your audience and what their day to day life looks like

I recommend doing all 4 vs just 1 of the above!

& remember, posting time is just one factor that the algorithm looks at — you still need to create quality and engaging content
