Honestly, sharing my failures hasn’t gotten any easier because who likes to admit that they’ve done things wrong or haven’t had success? Not me😂 

But I share it because I’ve realized on my journey as an entrepreneur that failures aren’t talked about anywhere near enough & I wish people spoke more openly about it

I remember having my first few disputed payments in my business and thinking about how big of a failure I was because I had never heard of anyone else struggling with disputes. & also because of that, I had no idea how to navigate disputes

Since then I’ve talked to many business owners and know that disputes are common but what I wish is that people normalized talking about failures more openly (or not even just failures, but the not so glamorous parts of being a business owner)

In order to be a 6, multi 6, or 7 figure business owner, you will fail. Many many times. Over and over and over again. It’s required for you to grow. It’s essential for you to grow.

So stop avoiding failure and instead embrace it as a stepping stone towards your goals 

→ I challenge you to drop a failure that you’ve had recently in the comments! Let’s normalize failures and even celebrate them knowing that they are part of the process

Now let me start off by saying…

You don’t need to do every single one of these things. Choose 1 or 2 to focus on and then add on more if reach and engagement still aren’t picking up 

1- consume less, create more — I don’t necessarily mean post more (though that is something you could experiment with), what I mean is spend more time in your creative zone of genius vs just running through the motions of posting. I also think that sometimes just getting out of your head and not being so focused on the numbers is a great way to break lose from the slower growth & find the fun in IG again

2- repurpose top performing content — look at top performing content from 3-4 months ago and repurpose it (not repost). Turn carousels into reels or vice versa. Or just simply take a reel that did well in the past and post an updated version 

3- spend time interacting with your community — turn to your community & make sure you’re getting feedback on what they want to see + making them feel like a part of your business by asking for opinions, suggestions, and feedback 

4- look at the data and adjust — this is a great time to get deep in the data. I recommend creating a spreadsheet so you can see your data from a new perspective and adjust your strategy based on your findings (I teach this in IGU)

5- focus on improving reach & business outside of IG — start and/or build your email list, focus on website SEO, better your marketing for offers, pitch podcasts to be a guest speaker, etc.

6- do an explore page analysis — look at the structure and format of the content to see what’s working on IG right now & take notes

7- simplify your content — go back to the basics: is your content save worthy? is your content capturing AND holding attention? is it clear who your content is for & what problem it solves? does your follower have a clear “next step” after each post? sometimes we forget about the basics in the hustle and bustle of business 

Bonus — give yourself grace! I promise you’re not the only one who has slower growth or lower reach + engagement on Instagram

Here’s the thing…

Selling, learning to sell, launching, marketing, messaging, funnels, etc. are all important but they mean nothing if your customer experience is crap

If you really want to build a stellar business, you need to look at your customer experience

Why? Because you want your customers to not just get results but have a good experience (an above and beyond experience hopefully) while getting those results 

+ good customer experience is what keeps people in your world aka creates repeat customers 

Here are a few ideas to get you started:

1- welcome emails w/ tips on how to get the most out of the offer
2- reminder emails + texts before live calls with easy access to the link to join
3- unexpected lil gifts + bonuses
4- knowing them by name & recognizing them outside of your offer
5- handling complications + issues (tech especially) with responsibility 
6- giving homework after trainings so your customers know what to implement
7- quick response times + helpful responses for customer support
8- easy access to the offer 
9- follow up emails to check-in on progress + remind them of what they should be doing
10- affiliate opportunities so they can make $$$ sharing your offer (if they want)
11- showing them they aren’t just a number (sticky notes w/ names or posting in a FB group every week about new members or do a customer appreciation highlight each week)
12- offboarding email with next steps + recap

Let me know in the comments what little things aren’t little for you as a customer ↓

My guess? Most post 90-100% value based content on their feed — they give freely using their feed as a resource for people to plug into

1. They understand that content is often people’s first introduction to their brand & want to make a good first impression (do they get hit with tangibles they can implement or a sales promo right off the bat??)
2. They leverage other places on and off the platform to sell 
3. They recognize the power of giving value to peoples lives even if they never make a purchase — their focus is on the people, not the numbers
4. They understand that giving before the ask builds trust which creates lifelong customers + raving fans 
5. They understand that their feed content isn’t a sales strategy

So what is for selling? A sales page is for selling. An email funnel/emails are for selling. Stories are for selling. End of free masterclasses are for selling. Ads are for selling. DMs are for selling. Descriptions below videos/podcasts are for selling. 

But your content and your feed are for GIVING.

NOW, don’t get me wrong — use the CTA in your caption to sell your community on an offer but only AFTER you’ve shared the value

→ If you want to build something that is long lasting & well known, create content from a place of GIVE, not ask.

There’s a reason why you hear the quote “The average millionaire has 7 streams of income” often. 

Now, I’m not saying you need to have 7 income streams day 1 of your business. Maybe not even 7 after a year into business. 

But overtime it’s important to build your income streams so you’re not relying on just 1 thing to make $$

So with that being said, here are 10 other online income streams you can think about incorporating:

1- Making $$ from social media: reels bonus (no longer active but an example of an income stream you could’ve had — also a great example of why you shouldn’t just focus on 1 stream), IG gifts, YouTube payouts, TikTok creator fund, etc. While this income usually isn’t a lot, even a little bit every month makes a big difference over time

2- Affiliate commission: yes, you can sign up for Amazon or LTK but you should also reach out to creators who you’ve purchased offers from and see if they have an affiliate program that you can join so you can make $$$ sharing an offer that has benefited you. On top of that, think about tools/platforms/apps you use that have affiliate programs

3- Subscriptions: this could be instagram subscriptions or you can use platforms like patreon or my favorite, kajabi (link in bio for a 30 day free trial), where you can create membership type offers and build recurring revenue

4- Live events: this could be hosting a retreat (people pay to attend), speaking at an event (you charge to give a training), or mastermind events

5- Book: write a book and publish it on amazon! I have a guest training in IG University on writing a book if you want more info

6- Brand partnerships: there are SO many brands looking to partner with creators to increase their visibility and get their message out there. And brand partnerships don’t have to look like a sponsored reel. It could be an email campaign, partnering to create an offer/product together, co-hosted webinars, + more

7- UGC (user generated content): this is different from brand partnerships because with UGC you don’t have to post the content on your own account. With UGC you create content for a brand that they can post on their media outlets

Let’s break down WHY each of these things are important:

1. Niche down & get specific on my ideal follower: nicheing down has been a marketing technique used for ages now and it works. It’s proven to work. Niche down and then expand to other topics later on once you’ve built your community 

2. Collaborate with 2 accounts per month: this is a sure way to increase your reach and build credibility. Double the accounts double the reach for a post 

3. Go live once a week: this is less about an immediate return of followers and more about building a community. When you build a community people are more likely to engage with your content and that helps build your following

4. Post 5x a week - 2 carousels and 3 reels: a good amount in terms of quantity so you have data to create a strategy and adjust but also not so much that you use lose quality 

5. Share my opinions & get vulnerable day 1: it’s easier said than done but if you want to build something that stands out then YOU need to be shining through on your account. Anyone can post tips and tricks 

6. Do a competitor analysis to find gaps in the industry: this will help you create a strategy in terms of what topics aren’t being talked about, where there is “white space” in the industry (space for you to stand out and be unique), and it will help you understand where others strengths lie

7. Optimize my account (bio, pinned content, feed, highlights, SEO): this is pretty self explanatory but this is key to converting viewers into followers. Use your IG like your business storefront

8. Focus on getting people to spend time on my posts: this is a key indicator to the algorithm that people like your content and it will help your content get pushed to a larger audience (non followers)

9. Analyze my insights & focus on follows per post, non follower reach, and explore page reach: these 3 metrics are really important in understanding whether your content is hitting home with your community and creating visibility so you can keep growing

Let’s talk all things collaboration ↓

Q: what is collaborating?
A: collaborating is when you work with another account on IG to bring a message to both of your audiences. When collaborating on posts or reels the likes, comments, and shares are shared between the two account

Q: what types of collabs can you do?
A: you can collaborate with reels, posts, and lives. If you choose to create a reel or post you will want to use the collaboration feature so the content shows up on both of your accounts. If you choose to do a live collab one person will start the live and then accept the invite from the other person when they request to be a part of the live 

Q: what types of accounts should you collab with?
A: I suggest collaborating with other accounts in your niche or accounts in an adjacent niche to yours (ex: if you are in the healthy food space an adjacent niche might be in the fitness space). Adjacent meaning that their content is still beneficial for your audience (they still have a similar ideal follower) but is different than what you teach on

Q: how do you find accounts to collab with?
A: I recommend reaching out to people that you currently follow or are familiar with when it comes to a collab so when you pitch them on a collab in DMs you can share why you want to work with them, why you like their content, and even how long you’ve been following them (& they might even recognize you as a follower and someone who has interacted with them in the past). That being said you can also find people by typing keywords into the search bar on Instagram that relate to the title of the person you’d want to collab with and then you can reach out via DM and present them with the idea that you have for the collab. OR if you are looking for people who are already open to collaborating, check out my reel titled “IG growth tips that ACTUALLY work part 2” a few reels back where people in the comments have shared that they are open to and looking for people to collab with!

There’s always an answer to any problem, it just might take a little digging to find it!! 

1- Showing the bts of my business: when don’t I let my community in on what I’m doing they don’t feel like they’re a part of the action and don’t feel as connected to my business because they don’t know the why and how to what I’m doing. Bts looks like sharing sneak peeks of offers or the building of offers, daily tasks, conversations, thoughts, and even struggles

2- Not selling/marketing my offers at all or enough: as an online business owner, selling daily is what keeps the “open” sign on in my business. I never know when someone is going to come to my account (new or current follower) and be looking for what support provide. Selling daily doesn’t mean it all has to be on IG though. I utilize emails + traffic and funnels from other places to sell as well. Note: better marketing and selling of offers could also be the issue

3- Asking more than I’m giving: when I’m giving the most I’m always making the most — Content, podcasts, masterclasses, emails. Part of this comes back to the norm of reciprocity which tells us that we repay in kind what another has done for us aka when we give for free people feel an obligation to return the favor. But the other part is that I want my business to be built on the basis of giving because it’s something I value. And the more I give, the more grateful I find myself and the more grateful I am the better my business runs. Always. 

4- Visibility: not showing up on social media whether that be on feed or on stories leads to lack of sales because in order for a business to grow it needs visibility and for me, visibility comes from social media which boils down to showing up and creating content. Note: if you’re doing all the other things listed and sales are still low I’d look at the visibility of your business/offers

5- Not promoting offers at different price points & for different parts of my ideal customers journey: everyone is at a different stage in their journey and by promoting offers at different price points & for different pain points, I allow people to join my world where it’s best for them.

Here’s the truth —

It’s taken me a while to build my business to be in a place where this type of income comes in without me having to show up 24/7 — and even with time, I just want to share that nothing is ever truly “passive”. There is always work required even when it comes to passive income

Okay now let’s dive in to all the details…

A look at how I showed up in my business while on vacation (all batched & scheduled in advance - except my vacay stories):
•I posted 1x on instagram on Mon 
•I had a podcast episode go live on Tues 
•I had an educational email sent out on Thurs 
•daily IG stories with pictures from vacation & 3 stories that sold my minimind 

Where my income came from while on vacation:
•$3497 from small group coaching
•$2197 from a payment plan for 1:1 coaching from a student who signed up a few months ago
•$2084 from IGU monthly subscription 
•$1800 from IGU yearly subscription
•$1170 from Scalability payment plans from when the program was run in May
•$4175 from other offers sold passively during the week through my funnels

All of my income except 1 payment came from a recurring income source or a passive funnel

So what can you learn from this and implement into your business? There are 2 main things:

1- THE POWER OF RECURRING REVENUE: recurring meaning that you get paid out repeatedly vs just a one time payment. This revenue comes from subscriptions, recurring affiliate commission, and payment plans. Your focus should be on creating at least one income source in your business that produces recurring revenue

2- THE POWER OF PASSIVE SALES FUNNELS: over $5k of my sales while on vacation came from my passive sales funnels. This funnel is set up strategically to help me sell offers (low to high ticket) even when I’m not actively selling. You should have at least one passive sales funnel set up to convert freebie subscribers into customers by selling multiple offers to them

My second to last viral reel was a video of me sitting at my desk but the concept behind why it performed so well (again, my guess) lines up perfectly with my theory around why the second reel in this experiment performed better than the first

My other viral reel kept people watching the reel start to finish because they had to keep watching in order to see all of the tips I was sharing (tips weren’t shared in the caption, only additional information in the caption). It was a longer reel, 15 seconds, so it ranked higher because time spent on the post was longer and because it shows the algorithm that people really liked the content if they were willing to stick around for longer

So ultimately what does this all mean for you???
1- Focus on watch time for your reels and getting people to stick around longer
2- Master the art of capturing AND holding attention so you can create longer reels
3- Get people to stay on the post longer by directing them to the caption or to the comment section (and no I don’t just mean leave a CTA that says “leave a comment”, get creative!)

Now this doesn’t mean that you can’t be successful by posting shorter reels — there needs to be strategy behind how you show up and I think a balance of shorter and longer is best! + you’ve gotta do what makes the most sense in terms of how the information you share can be best presented and consumed by your community!

You can have shorter reels that go “viral for you” and bring in lots of followers too! What I shared in this post is just another thing to experiment with when it comes to your own content!

P.S.- this is my theory based on my experiences, experimenting, and data. This is not necessarily algorithm fact! Just sharing what i’ve been learning!

3 Prompts for Magic Write on Canva:
1- Once you have text written in a document (like an outline for a training), select the text and hit “summarize” to get a summary of what you’ve written that you can use in sales copy!
2- “Paraphrase this: [insert long form written content]” - then you that paraphrase as show notes for a podcast episode, IG story content to promote the long form content, or in an email
3- “Structured outline for a [insert what you want an outline for]” - then you can go in and build out the full script or document

3 Prompts for Kajabi AI Creator Hub:
1- Go to “course outline” and type in your course topic
2- Go to “lesson content” and type in a specific topic in your course that you want to outline. I love this feature because it also will give you a “lesson summary” which is super helpful to use to create homework for the training or make it easy for people to recap what they learned
3- Go to “sales email copy” and type in your course topic and get an outline for a sales email so you don’t have to start from scratch when prompting your course

3 Prompts for Chat GPT:
1- “What are the top 5 biggest misconceptions in [insert your niche/industry] and how can I debunk them?”
2- “Act as if you’re a [insert title of expertise]. [Then describe who your ideal follower is]. [Then describe what you want Chat GPT to do. 3- “In a minute I’m going to ask you to create a [insert content type] for me. I want you to ask me 15 to 20 questions to better understand my customers, my business, my audience , values and my tone of voice.”

There are no prompts needed for Pictory or Fireflies AI

IMPORTANT NOTE: As always, I recommend using AI as a companion tool, a base to get started and build off of. Nothing can replace you and your voice!

I’ve been asked a LOT over the last few days what the strategy to Threads should be - hashtags or no hashtags? how often to post? to sell or not sell? & the questions go on.

Here’s my answer... HAVE FUN. Enjoy being a beginner on the platform with everyone else — no one is ahead and no one is behind, we are all figuring it out together

Let this platform be a humanization of your business aka let this platform be a place where you truly share the real and raw

Now to shift the conversation — let me answer a few other FAQs…

There are many things that play a role in reels ranking higher in the algorithm but there are some things that have more weight than others 

🚨One of those factors is WATCH TIME🚨

& I’m not just talking about getting a viewer to watch the first few seconds of your reel

Yes that’s important because if you don’t hook them then, you never will

But I’m also talking about engaging a viewer for long enough that they watch your ENTIRE reel & you get bonus points if you get them to watch the reel multiple times!

So how do you do that? Here are a few prolonged watch time techniques:

➡️use spread text techniques— instead of having all of your text show up at once after the hook, spread it out so it shows up on screen one at a time (see my recent post titled “8,000 followers from 1 reel?” for more on this). the goal? to create a longer reel that people stay on longer. my theory is that longer reels with great watch time outperform short reels with great watch time

➡️use eye catching techniques— adding personality, transitions, adding pictures (like in this reel), cutting the video in a unique way, timelapses, or simply the text (& colors) you use on screen 

➡️use looping techniques— make it so the end of your reel flows into the start of your reel, people will watch the reel several times without even realizing

➡️use curiosity techniques— make your followers look for something in the reel that they may have to watch your reel a few times to find (a hidden tip, emoji, etc) 

➡️use storytelling techniques— stories are one of the best ways to engage a viewer. think about how you’d teach or share a concept with a friend and then present it in your content the same way. this is great for reels with a voiceover or face to camera talking

➡️use drawn own techniques— have a super engaging hook and then have a few seconds before any text shows up so viewers keep watching to see what you share. You can even use text that pops up that says “wait for it…” or “keep watching!”

Full breakdown of all 6 tips below + 2 bonus tips!!

1- offer an alumni (discounted) price to former a customer to re-sign or join something again: send out an email to all former customers who have done 1:1 with you and offer a discounted price to sign up again OR if you have a live program you run multiple times you can offer a discount for people to join the live program again!

2- send out a 24 hour flash sale email: choose one of your offers to discount and send out a “Christmas in July” email letting them know that this is your last big sale before the holidays!

3- add an upsell to an offer: an upsell is an additional offer that is presented at checkout for a customer to buy (main offer might be a course for $127 and then an upsell might be an ebook for $47)

4- bundle your top selling offers together and sell them for a limited time: give a good discount for the bundle and offer it for 48-72 hours

5- go live with one of your students to talk about their experience in your offer + their results: if you don’t have a student to go live with, go live by yourself and educate for 3-5 minutes on a topic that leads well into your offer — share some education and then pitch your offer 

6- sign up as an affiliate for things you already share weekly: write down a list of all the tools/programs you use and then sign for their affiliate programs and create a “fav things” highlight that shares all of your fav things and links using your affiliate code 

Bonus tips—
7- send out an email offering students the option to pay the program off early who are on a payment plan, honoring the pay in full price
8- add a limited time payment plan option for an offer that is currently only pay in full

[More tips + info below!!]

If you’re looking for a good output (answer from chat GPT), you need to have a good input. The more information you give chat GPT, the better. 

Things I highly recommend giving detailed information on in your input…
•who you are and what you do
•who your ideal follower/customer is
•what your offer is and who it’s for 
•the outcome/result for someone who goes through your offer
•what type of offer (course, 1:1 coaching, masterclass, live vs not live, etc)
•tone of voice
•price point and dates (if applicable) of offer

So if you aren’t getting good output, you need to have a better input

And to really help you with getting more engaging marketing copy in your output, tell chat GPT to use well known writing formulas that will elevate the marketing! Here are a few formulas you can tell it to use:

-Before - After - Bridge (BAB)
-Problem - Agitate - Solve (PAS)
-Attention - Interest - Desire - Action (AIDA)
-Picture - Promise - Proof - Push (4 P’s framework)
-Features - Advantages - Benefits (FAB)

Note: on the prompts that say part 1, part 2, etc… those are multi step prompts so write out part 1 and send it to chat GPT and then send part 2 and so on so forth (like having a conversation with the bot)

A few points I want to expand on…

1- use motion/multiple clips to capture & hold attention: in the first clip of this reel I was moving and then the second clip was a different view. You don’t have to do crazy transitions to be successful. Other things you can do: timelapse, use apps like inshot or capcut to zoom in or out in a video, film a daily task you do, move your tripod and record from different angles

2- implement prolonged watch time techniques: I talked about this in more depth two reels ago so go check that reel out!

3- ditch the generic hooks: you know what I’m talking about… the “how to ___” and “5 tips for ___”. If you want your content to stand out, it starts with your hook. 
Unique hook examples: 
•ditch __ & do __ instead
•steal my ___
•3 ___ you can do right now: ___ edition
•a simple change that made __ easier
•do this for less ___
•learn to create ___ in under ___ min
•have you ever tried ___?

4- make sure all of your reels aren’t structured the same: structure meaning that all of your reels don’t look the same. When all of your reels look the same they aren’t scroll stopping. Keep people on their toes! Example: all of your reels timelapses
Example 2: all of your reels are 4 seconds long with a hook and then a CTA that says “read the caption for __”

5- set a goal/purpose for each reel: instead of the purpose being “virality” set a specific goal for each reel. 
Example: this reel is to create a deeper connection with my audience
Example 2: this reel is to drive traffic to my new 15 day challenge
Get really intentional with why you are creating each reel and this will help you measure success of the reel in different ways than just views!

I’m gonna be completely transparent with you….

This isn’t an extensive list because there is a LOT that goes into scaling to higher income months while working less but these are the KEY pieces that have helped get me there…

1/ Auditing my time: this was huge in helping me cut down on hours while still scaling. For a whole week I tracked every task I did + how much time it took. Then at the end of the week I reviewed each task and ranked them in order of importance. Most important being tasks that directly bring in sales for my business. Now, each day starts with those tasks (income producing activities) & all other tasks get done if I have time 

2/ Hiring help: my first hire helped me cut down on 2-3 hours of work per week, saving me 8-9 hours a month. my second hire helped me cut down on another 2-3 hours a week, saving me another 8-9 hours a month. Just from 2 employees, I’m getting back 16-18 hours a month. I now have 5 people on my team. Don’t be afraid to delegate & ask for help. 

3/ Automations & Systems: there are SO many tasks that are done on a daily/weekly basis that can be automated or sped up using a system. When you do your time audit, ask yourself with each task if it’s something you can automate! Examples: follow up emails, feedback collection, and even DM responses can be automated 

4/ Asking myself this question: how can I make making $__k a month even easier? This has led me to focus on improving my business where it’s at vs always looking to do more to make more — as I improve my business I am not only able to make money easier at that level, but scale to the next level easier

5/ Marketing superpower: finding what drives the most traffic to my business & honing in on that one thing vs trying to do it all

First off… can you guess what I’m going to say??

There’s not a one size fits all strategy here. Each business is so different and should approach pricing based on its goals, experience, offer, etc. 

Did you guess that?😂

Pricing is really an art and a science. Both strategy and intuition need to be at play — strategy being steps 1-4 and intuition being step 5 (in my formula below)

All that being said, here is my no fluff formula for pricing:

1/ reverse engineer my pricing:

I work backwards from my goal, to my volume, to the price of my offer

what is my income goal? 
how many people can I bring inside my offer on a monthly basis?
How much do I need to charge to hit my income goal?

2/ what do I want to profit from the offer?

I take the price I need to hit my income goal and then I think about profit. I factor in fees (payment processing fees) as well as expenses to keep the offer running (paying employees, subscriptions, marketing, equipment, etc)

3/ where does this fit in your offer suite? + how can the offer be used in more ways than one?

How does this offer fit in with your other offers and how does this fit into your customers journey? (I teach alllll about this in Scalability)

4/ industry standards 

I then look at industry standards to see where my pricing, that I’ve already chosen, lies amongst competitors. Now, I don’t look because I’m comparing. I look because pricing says a lot more about your offers than you realize — Price too low and people may think it’s low quality, price too high (unless your positioning is a luxury niche) then people might go elsewhere to get help

Knowing your positioning effects pricing and knowing industry standards helps you to make sure you’re not low balling the value you provide

Here’s what people don’t talk about when it comes to story views. If someone isn’t watching your stories it doesn’t matter how strategic your stories are because they aren’t watching them. On top of that, there are only a few things that can be done on your stories alone to get more people to see your stories

Yes, post the interactive polls and quizzes. Yes, make sure your stories are engaging. Yes, implementing storytelling on stories. 
Yes, encourage interaction. 
Yes, keep people watching for longer. 

But a great story strategy needs to be paired with a great traffic strategy that leads people to your stories!

Let people know in other places on IG why they should watch your stories and what they are missing out on if they don’t tune in!

Okay now back to the tips…

3- TAKE A 24 HOUR BREAK
This will reset your stories & help boost views temporarily — I don’t recommend doing this more than 2x a month. Make sure that your first few stories back after the break are using interactive features. Also, this is not a “strategy” this is more of a hack

4- GIVE CONTEXT 
This is most important for selling on stories without losing viewers. Before jumping into sales content, give context to the offer and why you’re posting about it. & as you keep more people on stories (don’t have people swiping out) the more the algorithm will bump up your story bubble on other peoples story feed

5- FAVORITES FEED
Get people to add you to their favorites feed so your content shows up higher on their feed (the home feed)

I was chatting with someone the other day who mentioned that seeing business owners post their own wins is a turnoff & they’d rather see client wins

You need to know that who you are investing in is credible & one way that this is done is through business owners sharing their own wins and successes

But how do you do it tastefully?

As a society we have been conditioned to believe what we see and doubt what we hear which means that you need to showcase your credibility through embodiment vs just stating the win. 

Show, don’t just tell — be a living breathing example of what you teach by showcasing it through your daily actions

One of my biggest pet peeves is when I see content that talks about passive income as if there’s no work involved once the income stream is set up

It’s just simply not true. 

Now there are ways you can get your business to a place where things are pretty dang passive but even then, there’s still one key piece needed for passive income streams to work that will never be 100% passive…

& that is VISIBILITY 

You need to drive traffic to your passive income stream(s) which means posting on social media, running ads, etc. All of which take time and energy

I am a big believer in building passive income and I think everyone should have passive income streams set up but don’t get caught up in the notion that passive = no work

Here are few passive income streams that are about as passive as you can get as an online business owner:
-subscriptions/memberships (aka building recurring revenue)
-affiliate programs that payout recurring commission
-courses or any offer that is ran evergreen (aka not ran live)

I posted on stories the other day asking which piece of content you wanted to see next and the title of this post option was “a tip for having higher income days/months”

While I’m guessing no one expected the answer to be this, the tip is simple…

[IF YOURE NOT GETTING, GIVE MORE]

It’s newtons law — for every action there is an equal and opposite reaction (& yes I know that this law isn’t meant to be related to business but it works lol)

But why is sharing for free so powerful? 

→ let’s be real here, who doesn’t love free stuff? people love getting things for free & it makes them feel more connected to your business + more likely to support you. In psychology they call it the “norm of reciprocity”. This norm requires that we repay in kind what another has done for us aka when we give for free, people feel a certain obligation to give back

→ people get to see a sample of what it is that you’ll provide inside of a paid offering when they’re in your freebie — they can test the waters before jumping in

→ people buy from people they trust and a great way to build trust is to give them something for free

→ you have to spend money to make money. while in a service based industry, to give something for free doesn’t necessarily cost money (a free ebook, masterclass, challenge), the concept still applies. whenever I run a free masterclass, my sales increase. whenever I share my email freebies, my sales increase.

The last thing I’ll leave you with is this…

Being afraid to give away too much for free is a lack mentality (not abundance) that will hold you back from being successful. 

But the only way you can give and get something back is if you’re selling alongside the giving. You can give all day but if people don’t know about your offers then sales won’t increase. 

[BECAUSE I GIVE A LOT, I ALSO SELL A LOT]

Don’t be afraid to share about your offers daily and in different ways (stories, email, podcasts, etc)

You’ve probably seen people use this CTA before (you’ve definitely seen me use it) but understanding the WHY behind it is really important…

1- by taking away the step where people have to go tap the link in your bio and dig for the link you’re referring to, you are going to increase conversions because more clicks = less conversions which means less clicks = more conversions 

2- it makes your audiences life easier because you’re doing the heavy lifting for them by sending them the link

3- by sending a DM you are opening up conversation and potential customers are more likely to ask questions and share their pain points — having conversations increase conversions

Some fun and interesting stats:
-Studies have found that just one reply in messenger can increase the likelihood of conversion by 50%; one more reply makes that visitor 100% more likely to convert. A simple conversation with 6 exchanged messages makes a visitor 250% more likely to become a customer.
-Research has shown there to be a 10% increase in the average order value when customers engage in live chat before making a purchase

Note: this works for ANY creator on instagram who is sharing links (product, service, influencer, etc)

I was asked this question recently and then a few days later I was on YouTube & saw a video titled exactly that… “how to create 3 months worth of content in 3 hours” & I felt like it was a sign to talk about this topic

First thing I have to say is… I’m not sure it’s possible lol. I honestly don’t think I could create that volume of content in 3 hours — unless you’re repurposing a bunch of content or already have videos filmed or ideas prepped, it’s gonna be pretty dang hard

Side note… what does “create” actually mean? like just have ideas laid out? or like have every post created and ready to post (caption, audio, hook, etc)? 

But anyways, now for the conversation I really want to get into which is WHY I don’t recommend it

[Whether or not it’s realistic to do, strategically it’s not going to serve you best]

If you create content only 4x a year it’s going to be hard to stay relevant because you aren’t keeping up with your audiences current needs and important trending topics

Also, instagram changes often and with those changes comes a need for a change in strategy and while you definitely don’t need to switch up your strategy monthly, you do need to make adjustments frequently to make sure your content is helping move you towards your goal(s)

Lastly, you’re only going to have 4 chances a year to look at your insights and adjust your content which isn’t enough — that’s like saying that you only check how much money you’re making in your business 4x a year, kinda hard to know how things are working and what to adjust when you’re not checking in on the data regularly 

To sum it up, if you’re really looking for growth on IG you need to stay up to date on not just what is happening on the platform, but more importantly how your content is resonating with your audience and what content they are needing to support them in their journey

Now let me start off by saying that I am NOT saying that you can’t ever use “how to” or “5 tips” hooks again, you definitely can

But the way consumers look at hooks is changing which means you need to change too if you still want to create content that connects

Here are 3 examples of how to reframe your hooks…

PAIN POINT REFRAME—
Instead of: how to optimize your account for SEO
Try using: increase your account reach in 2 easy steps

STORYTELLING REFRAME—
Instead of: 5 tips to hit $100k months
Try using: people don’t really understand what it takes to hit $100k months…

QUESTION REFRAME—
Instead of: how to grow 1000 followers
Try using: what would an extra 1k followers do for your business?

It’s simple… create content like you’re telling a story OR reframe the hook to touch on pain points so you’re speaking directly to what your audience wants (vs being a text book chapter heading)

Crafting compelling hooks doesn’t need to be difficult!

Yesterday in a question box I got asked whether or not the challenge is still effective

I have a lot of thoughts so buckle up

When I started the 30 day reel challenge I knew little to nothing (in comparison to what I know now) about instagram & took on the challenge because I saw a lot of other creators doing it and grow thousands of followers

As you know though, 30 days did nothing for me so I ended up doing a 90 day challenge

Looking back I can say that it wasn’t the challenge itself that helped me grow, it was what I learned during those 90 days that led to my success

Heres what I learned…
1- how to be consistent & how to create a system so I could show up without creating 24/7 (this led me to batching content). even after the 90 days I continued to post daily
2- how to be a good content creator — through putting out high volumes of content I figured out what worked vs what didn’t and how to create quality content (quantity drove quality)
3- I failed fast which allowed me to succeed — failed content helped me to learn (& I failed a LOT)
4- the data helped me to know how to not just adjust my strategy, but create one + learn the algorithm. I spent a lot of time looking at the numbers and changing my approach

I share this because I know many people who do the challenge and nothing changes and I think it’s because it’s one thing to do the challenge and it’s another to LEARN from the challenge (aka are you looking at the data and adjusting?)

So the question is… do I still recommend the 30 reel challenge?

Yes & no.

If you want to do the challenge to push yourself and also for what you’ll learn (like what I shared above like getting consistent), go for it. But if you’re just doing it to grow by thousands then don’t

IG has changed massively since the 30 day reel challenge became popular 2 years ago which means that the outcome of the challenge then vs now has also massively changed

The challenge was started to get accounts a lot of growth success in a short period of time but the challenge now is more so for getting out of your comfort zone and into a routine

There are a lot of things that are needed to start a business but looking back these are the things I’d do first/focus on most!

Bonus: I would sell my offer DAILY after launching it

If you had to restart your business from scratch what would you focus on? Let me know in the comments!!

Tips 6-9 below↓

NUMBER 1-
Create a freebie + tripwire to grow & monetize my email list from day 1

I would create one of these 4 freebies: quiz, webinar, challenge, or pdf download

I wouldn’t worry about extensive email funnels, I would implement those later on in my journey

NUMBER 2-
Do a few 1:1 coaching sessions to get ideas on what offers to create

Even if I wasn’t going to do 1:1 long term, this would help me to better understand my audiences needs

NUMBER 3-
Spend more time learning how to sell

If I had to choose just 1 thing to go back and redo, it would be this. Focusing more on how to sell. Sales skills are so important (if not THEE most important skill as a business owner)

NUMBER 4-
Create + sell 3 offers at different price points (low $ to high $$$$)

I wouldn’t do this all at once but start with 1 offer and then launch it and then move to the next offer

NUMBER 5-
Focus heavily on building exposure on 1 social platform for my business

I wouldn’t hop on every social media platform. I would just focus on growing on Instagram and building my email list

NUMBER 6-
Invest in courses/offers that teach me specific skills I need to learn

NUMBER 7-
Systemize/automate tasks asap

The sooner you put systems into place (especially ones that can be automated), the easier it will be for you to scale and hire support + they will help you work less from day 1

NUMBER 8-
Share more testimonials as case studies

I would have a heavier focus on collecting information that I could share in a case study vs just as a testimonial because case studies are more powerful in bringing in new customers

NUMBER 9-
Add order bumps to all offers

This helps you to make MORE from the same effort. How? You’re still driving traffic to the main offer (through selling) but now your potential revenue isn’t just $47 per sale, it’s $67, for example.

For a while I genuinely thought that the only way my business was “successful” and growing was if my income was increasing each month

If my income dipped one month, I felt like I had failed. If my income wasn’t increasing month over month, I felt like I had failed. 

This year, while I’ve had a few (very few) random income spikes, majority of the months I’ve brought in the same amount of income 

& about a month ago I started to really get down on myself about it. because looking around on IG, I’ve surrounded myself with people who are doing huge and amazing things like making more and more each month so I felt like that was the norm and I was behind

[Side note: every business has lower income months, we just don’t see those shared as often because they’re not as glamorous]

But after chatting with my coach I realized that growth + success are about more than just increasing income…

They can also look like… 
→ working less 
→ increasing profit margins 
→ delegating more/automations 
→ having more joy in your work 
→sustainability

So even though my income hasn’t looked like a linear line increasing this year, Ive realized how powerful it is to sustain a certain income level and overtime be able to work less — I’ve gone, just this year, from working 6-8 hour days 6x a week to 4-5 hour days 5x a week while making the same amount

The last thing I’ll leave you with is something my coach said to me in this same conversation and it’s really stuck with me. She said… “instead of always asking how you can make more, ask yourself how you can make what you’re already making even easier”

[Instead of always focusing on more, focus on easier]

Here’s the deal…

I get that visibility is important. I get that more followers can help get more sales. I get that more growth = more impact. 

Thats why I started my growth journey and that’s why I teach IG growth

But don’t forget that you can sell to the audience you have right now, you don’t have to wait to hit a certain follower number to be successful 

I bring up this conversation because I want you to get honest with yourself for a second…

→ Are you so caught up in the numbers on instagram that you’re forgetting to sell? 
→ When was the last time you sold your offer on instagram? 
→ Is most of your time spent refreshing your IG account or thinking about how you can strategically sell to your audience?
→ Do you believe that you have to have X amount of followers to make X amount of money?

My DMs are filled with people who are reaching out about how low their reach is right now (I get it, mine is too) and they’re worried about how it’ll impact their business. and while I truly get the concern, this is a great time to reassess your goals on IG and make sure that your actions are aligned

Some of my lowest reach periods have brought in the most amount of revenue in my business. Why? Because I’ve used that time to focus on leveraging what I already have vs only being focused on building — note: there is a time and a place for both focuses

If you keep showing up and putting in strategic effort, I promise that the low reach period will pass and you’ll see growth. But if you don’t sell, I can’t promise you’ll make $$$ 

[You need to put selling at the forefront of your actions and focus]

First off let me talk about why I decided to start posting less…

In January I realized that I wanted to shift my approach to visibility in my business to better fit my goals for the year & the lifestyle I wanted to live. Goals shifted, so my strategy shifted

Posting 6-12x a week was working for me so posting less had nothing to do with the results I was seeing — I really wanted to create space so I could pursue other content formats like podcasting and YouTube as well as leaning more into email marketing. 

Also, I kept hearing “you have to post daily to stay relevant” and I wanted to prove people wrong. So I also did it to experiment and see what posting less would do — I will never talk the talk and not walk the walk. I am always wanting to learn & grow so that I can teach based on my findings (one reason why this post itself is an experiment lol)

Okay, now for what I’ve learned posting less (I’ve learned a lot but these are the BIG things)…

1- There is power in creating content around trending topics: I had 2 posts this year that brought in over 15k followers alone because I jumped on hot topics and applied those to my niche and provided value

2- It’s been harder to post less: okay, I understand that this probably isn’t the case for most people but for whatever reason it was easier for me to show up consistently when I was posting daily AND I didn’t overthink my content so much. Posting less = more analysis paralysis (for me)

3- Quantity AND quality matter: I learned quality through quantity but now I can have less quantity because I have the quality BUT, I wouldn’t post any less than 3x a week. I actually think 4x a week is the optimal minimal number (hopefully that makes sense haha)

4- Having unique selling points is important: It’s not to say that I didn’t have unique content to share before this year but this year I’ve really leaned into the things that set me apart. One of those unique points being my experimenting

Lessons 5-9 in the comments (guess I have a lot to say on this topic lol)

More on each point below but first, I’d love to know… What is one lesson that your current season of life has taught you about business? Drop it in the comments ↓
I’d love to hear!!

1- not everyone sees everything you post or everything you sell:
DAILY I am getting messages saying “wait youre pregnant?!” and I’m due in 20 days haha. I feel like I talk about pregnancy a lot and have shared pictures multiple times a week but it’s been a great reminder to me that not everyone see everything I post which means that not everyone sees every time I sell. I need to be selling daily and it’s okay (& even strategic) to repurpose content

2- saying no is an important part of scaling:
let me preface this by saying that saying yes is also important especially at the beginning of your business. But for me as I’ve prepped for maternity leave I’ve turned down a lot of opportunities — I had to get picky with what I’m taking on so sometimes I turned down something good for something great. If I say yes to something in this season of life it means I am saying no to something else & is that worth it?

3- knowledge is power but only if it’s matched with action:
I’ve spent a lot of hours in birth prep classes as well as post birth classes. The more I know, the more confident and comfortable I feel going into birth BUT only if I apply that knowledge. This means putting the knowledge into practice — breathing exercises, meditation, visualization, getting spaces prepped. I’ve always been pro investing in business (gotta spend money to make money) but it’s been a good reminder to me to make sure I’m making time to implement what I learn

4- automations and systems are vital for scaling and working less: 
A big question I got asked in the Q&A box on stories yesterday was “how do you do it all?” — short answer… I don’t. I delegate. I automate. I have systems to streamline tasks and increase efficiency. I say no. All of which are key for working less and making more

Time for a little highlight update!!

Your offer highlight(s) should act a mini sales page for your offer so it’s important to keep it up to date and full of helpful information!

I love using my highlights in this way because it gives people easy access to find and learn about my offer without ever having to click off the IG platform 

Note: this doesn’t mean that websites and sales pages aren’t important. this isn’t meant to replace them, just simply add to the customer journey/experience

8 things to include + a bonus tip below:

1- why you created the offer + why you’re a credible source to learn from on the topic 
2- who the offer is for 
3- what the outcome/result of the offer is
4- what peoples current beliefs/feelings are on the topic vs what you believe/feel about it
5- the nitty gritty details: bonuses, call times, dates, etc
6- frequently asked questions
7- testimonials and/or case studies
8- behind the scenes look or breakdown of what’s inside

Bonus- create a post or freebie that gives people an example of the education they’ll get inside the offer and add that to your highlight

These 5 things are applicable no matter what stage of business you’re in!

Disclaimer: there are SO many moving pieces to scaling, a whole programs worth of info actually which is why I created scalability, this one reel alone can’t cover it all. So what I’m sharing are the 5 biggest things that have helped but this isn’t an all encompassing list🫶🏻

1- focused on improving my customer experience
For the longest time I was only focused on getting new customers vs creating repeat customers. This isn’t to say that I didn’t care for my current customers but I didn’t really do much for them/with them after they purchased. So setting up automations and taking the time to do the little things that go the extra mile has been powerful in creating more repeat customers which made it easier to make sales

2- added more strategy to my offer suite specifically with low cost offers 
Now this actually didn’t even look like doing more, it was just getting more strategic with what I already had and what I was already doing. This looked like… adding in upsells to all of my offers (upsell revenue this year alone = ~$25k), adding in downsells, adding in tripwires (tripwire revenue = ~$15k). And as for making $$$ from what I was already doing, I got more strategic about affiliate commission and making $$$ from things I was already using, sharing, and loving (affiliate commission this year = ~$10k)

3- delegated more. automated more.
Now I don’t just mean I hired more people. I actually didn’t hire any more people but I did delegate more of my tasks to the team I had already built. This isn’t something that I believe can just happen overnight, at least not for me, because the delegation of additional tasks came as I built trust with my team AND spent time really looking at the IPAs in my business and where I want to be spending my time. As for automations, I don’t just mean set up the FAQs in your DMs, yes that’s great but specifically automations that drive SALES while I sleep. ManyChat is a great tool for this!

Disclaimer: there is no one right way to build a business — you can be successful building something totally different than what I’ve listed here and that’s what’s so fun about being a business owner (imo). this is just my personal recommendation & the overview/map I wish I had seen when I started my business. Use this as a base and then adjust the structure to fit your goals and business! 

Since this is a long list, I’d use this as a checklist and work through 1 of these things at a time (I’d suggest focusing on 1 task every 1-2 months) vs looking at this as a “get this done tomorrow to be successful” type of list! 

As you build this out, every task will help you increase income and scale your business so you don’t need to have this all in place to make money

→ Have an offer structure question? Drop it in the comments below and I’ll get to as many as possible and, if applicable, refer you to an offer where I dive into the topic more in depth!

DEFINITIONS (what I personally mean when I use certain terms):
-funnel: an email sequence that brings a subscriber from awareness to action (aka getting them to purchase an offer) — this is a map of the customer journey 
-tripwire: a low cost offer that is presented to a subscriber after they opt in for a freebie
-recurring revenue: an income source that pays on a recurring basis like a subscription or membership or payment plans
-live offer: this offer is either totally live or the main component of the offer is live (think live programs, live masterclasses)
-evergreen offer: an offer that is for sale year round, always available for purchase (think courses, ebooks, templates)
-low ticket: a low cost offer (usually up to $150)
-mid ticket: a mid cost offer (usually between $200-$800)
-high ticket: a high cost offer (usually $1000+)
-affiliate program: a program that you set up for your offer where students can promote the offer to their community and receive a % commission when someone uses their link to sign up for the offer

Alrighty, think about this for a second…

You’re scrolling through the reels tab or maybe the explore page and you see a reel and decide to click on it…

WHY?

Yes, it might be because it has a catchy text box hook like “stop doing __ or else __” but odds are pretty high that you also stop on videos because of 3 other things…

1- the video content itself: idk about you but an aesthetic video definitely draws me in or when I see someone smiling in a video or the setting in the video is unique. an example: every time I share a reel where I’m walking on my treadmill at my desk people are drawn in. timelapses are another great example of the video content being engaging

2- the text placement: @latenightepiphanies_ and @karinaglennon do this really well with different text structures. people are so used to seeing the classic centered text box so adding in different styles can be powerful & eye catching which stops the scroll

3- visual hooks: this ties back into number 1 but it’s also different than number 1 in the sense that the video might not be super engaging but you can add a picture to increase interest. think: DM question, testimonial, proof of concept (money earned, growth, orders made, etc). I’d also say that remixing another reel would be under this category as well! 

bonus: colors! if it makes sense with your branding, playing around with colors of text boxes or colors in the video content can help draw people in as well

Hooking people with your content is about more than just the text box hook that you use (though that is a very important piece of your content), it’s about creating a visual hook too!

LETS TALK ABOUT YOUR BIO—

There are 5 main things I recommend leaving out of your bio but there are a few exceptions to my suggestions, let’s dive into it…

1- HASHTAGS
I don’t recommend anything in your bio that will take people away from your account. A hashtag will take people to all the posts under the hashtag and someone is likely to get lost after tapping on the hashtag & not make it back to your account — the exception: if it’s a branded hashtag that showcases your offers and will lead people back to your account then you can add it

2- CATEGORY LABELS
Now that the category label is a hyperlink (aka you can tap on it), having it in your bio shortens the amount of lines that you can have without the “more” button popping up meaning that if you have more than 3 lines in your bio the other lines are being hidden — in my opinion it’s more valuable to have an extra line in your bio than have the tappable category label 

3- MULTIPLE CTAs
I see a lot of bios that will have two CTAs like “follow for tips on __” and then “tap the link to join ___”. Give people ONE specific CTA, they are more likely to take action if you do and you should use that extra space in your bio to add other important info. You can always change up your CTA, I do multiple times a month on my account

4- FANCY FONTS
The first thing people think of when they see different than normal fonts is “how can I do that with my bio” aka it distracts from the information in your bio

5- OTHER TAGGED ACCOUNTS
Same as with hashtags, you don’t want to take people away from your account — the exception: if your own/run the other account and want to drive traffic there or if it helps with credibility (if you’re mentioning being featured in like Forbes or ABC or something like that, just state those vs tagging the accounts)

This is usually the part where people say… “I’ve tried it all” or “I’m doing that but it’s not working”

But there’s one thing most people aren’t focused on and it comes down to one word… “strategic” — it’s one thing to throw something new out there for the sake of “experimenting” and it’s another to strategically plan your experimenting with purpose and intent

So what does this look like?

Breaking down your experiments into categories & matching them with your IG goals

Let’s dive into a few examples but note that there are a lot more aspects to each of these…

REACH EXPERIMENTING: this type of experimenting is all about finding what works to increase your reach

Ex- you do a competitor analysis and find that there is a specific topic in your niche that you haven’t shared your opinion on, you  use that content to see if that topic is something your audience wants to hear more about and if it increases reach 

ENGAGEMENT BOOSTING EXPERIMENTING: this type of experimenting is all about finding what drives more interaction with your content

Ex- you use a CTA at the beginning of your caption vs at the end to see if more people interact because they aren’t getting to a CTA at the end of the caption

REPURPOSE EXPERIMENTING:
this type of experiment is all about getting strategic about what you’ve created in the past and using it in the present

Ex- you had a carousel post that flopped in July, you decide to take that post and turn it into a reel to see if it was the format people consume the information in that was off or if the content itself needs to be changed 

COLLAB EXPERIMENTING: 
this type of experimenting is all about finding out which type of collaboration works best for your goals

Ex- you have a goal of increasing followers, you decide to do a collab with 3 different accounts that are similar in size — each collab is a different type of collab (reel, post, live) and you measure to see which brought in the most followers 

Other types of experiments include: community building, copywriting, branding, & content pillar experiments, just to name a few

Before I share my tips… Is your account reaching non followers? If yes, share what’s working for you in the comments so we can all help each other out!

Recently there’s been a lot of talk about struggles with non follower reach so I wanted to share some thoughts

Let me start off by saying that there are no “hacks” for reaching non followers & the BEST thing you can do is pay attention to your analytics

But before I dive in, something that’s important to understand is how the algorithm works — if you can get your current followers to interact with your content the algorithm is more likely to push that content out to new people (aka non followers) AND the quicker the interaction from your current community the quicker the algorithm will push it out. So engagement from your current followers is a KEY player here that often gets overlooked because people are only wanting more and more new vs focusing on nurturing what they already have

So it might seem counterintuitive but you’ve gotta focus on your current followers in order to reach new followers 

Now that you understand that, let me share my best tips:

1- Post reels to just the reels tab (not to your feed + reels tab): I don’t recommend posting all reels here but when you post reels to only the reels tab you oftentimes will reach more non followers. This doesn’t always mean though that those non followers will convert into followers so you need to make sure that your account and content are optimized to convert. I only recommend 1-2 reels a month to just the reels tab & know that reels posted to the reels tab often will get significantly lower views than if it was also posted to your feed

2- Post when your audience is online: this helps your content get more engagement after posting which will help your content get pushed out by the algorithm — I’d also add that a consistent posting time is important 

3- Get on the explore page: there are many pieces to this, a whole lesson worth actually, but a big part of getting on the explore page is people sharing & saving your content and the other key piece is how quickly your community interacts with the content after you post it

A BIG mistake I see people make on instagram…

USING EVERY FEATURE/CONTENT FORMAT THE SAME

All of these formats are needed for success on IG but they don’t all help you achieve you the same thing

If you had to cross the ocean and you had a bike, car, and boat which would you choose?

All three will help transport you to an end destination but if you’re crossing the ocean you’re probably not going to choose the bike or car 

Same concept applies to content formats. You need to choose the best vehicle (format) to reach your destination. For example: if you want growth and reach stories and DMs aren’t the best avenue to get there, reels are

But not only does each format serve a different purpose, each one will help you reach different people if they’re used strategically

Why? Because our consumer habits control the content we see. So if different people like consuming different content formats and they interact with those formats, that leads different formats to reach different people

So using more features = more reach to different people

The last thing here with using formats differently is making sure you have a strategy 

Because each format serves a different purpose, you also need a different strategy for each format

You can’t treat carousels the same as reels or stories the same as lives. If you do you, won’t see the results you’re looking for

Which is why a lot of people struggle to grow… they aren’t optimizing each format for its unique purpose and role, they’re just simply posting to post which is like throwing darts at a board while blindfolded

Ask yourself, “how am i strategically approaching each format to help me hit my goals?”

BTS - if your business isn’t growing or working like you thought it would, I hope to encourage you with this. 
 
→ Maybe your Black Friday sale didn’t unfold as you hoped....
→ Maybe this quarter or year hasn’t met your expectations...
→ Maybe you’re uncertain about the next step....
→ Maybe life outside of business has just been really stressful or lonely...
 
You are not alone.
 
It can be so easy to scroll on social media and feel like you are the only one going through a challenging time or having a low income month or putting in effort and not seeing the results, and that couldn’t be farther from the truth.
 
Entrepreneurship is a full on up and down journey. A roller coaster. 
 
Every season has so much beauty, although it might be hard to see right now.
 
So before you start comparing yourself to others or going down the spiral, will you make me one promise?
 
Reflect on why you started your business in the first place and how far you’ve come.
 
Sometimes that’s what we need - time to reflect and remember ‘why.’
 
When your dream and vision is at the forefront of your thoughts, you can experience the highs and lows with the appreciation that it’s all about the journey.
 
Black Friday sale didn’t go as planned?
Didn’t celebrate 10 new students in your offer?

I remember when I first heard someone say this, it was when I had just started my business and was trying to grow my account

I immediate was like ya whatever, that’s not for me. I want to follow others in my niche to support them cuz collaboration>competition ya know?

But the further I’ve gotten into business the more I realize that it’s so true for more reasons than one

I first started to unfollow people in my niche because I found myself in a constant comparison loop. I had a few people who started their instagram growth journeys at the same time as me in the same niche and grew exponentially faster & I would constantly feel like I was doing something wrong. Something to think about — when was the last time you scrolled on instagram and walked away feeling good and not like you were behind?

The next thing that I realized is that I was getting compared to others in my niche a lot. In no way was I copying other people yet I was getting DMs saying “why should I buy from you vs __?” and I was frustrated because I didn’t want to be compared to anyone else, I wanted to be so unique that I was in a league of my own. To really stand out I knew I had to stop consuming so much of other people’s content in my niche and put on my tunnel vision goggles and create from a place that is 100% my own & lemme tell ya it’s been a game changer

Then, later on I heard @samvanderwielen talking about this, I believe in a podcast episode, and she mentioned something that just clicked for me — I don’t remember word for word what was said but it was along the lines of… how does following other people in your niche support them? you’re not their ideal client or follower, you’re not going to buy from them. & it’s so true — a common question IG University students ask is how to attract followers that aren’t people in their own niche, and while it’s inevitable that it’ll happen, my students understand the power of attracting their ideal follower vs others in their niche

While there are a lot of great things to do before posting a reel — these 5 things are what I believe are the most important and have the biggest effect on the performance of the reel and growth of your account 

1//
Ask yourself - “if someone saw this reel on the explore page would they understand my niche?”

This is one of the most impactful questions you can ask yourself before posting. If you are reaching new eyes those new eyes are usually only seeing one piece of your content (on explore, reels tab, someone’s stories) which then determines if they click on your profile to see your account so it’s important for that content to reflect your niche & overall message 

2//
Write down - the specific goal of the reel 

This is a whole training in itself, one that’s in IG University actually, but you want to make sure that you define the goal of the reel — do you want it to help nurture and build community? do you want it to increase sales? do you want it to bring in new eyes? do you want it to create engagement?

3//
Match - the CTA to the goal of the reel

Once you know the goal of the reel you want to match your CTA to that goal. Ex: if your goal is to build community, you might have a CTA that asks your followers to play 2 truths and a lie in the comments so you can get to know them better!

4//
Double check - that you have a stand-out hook 

If your hook doesn’t stand out, people won’t consume your content so it’s vital to create a hook that really captures the value of the info inside the reel but also captures attention — think simple yet effective here

The power of the link in bio…

I upgraded my link in bio at the end of January this year and it really has been a game changer. So much so that when I got a new website design last month, focus on the link in bio page was TOP priority and where I had my designer spend the most time to make sure it was easy to navigate and not overwhelming

I’ve gotten SO much great feedback about my link page (branding on pointttt) and increased conversions (aka more $$$) but that’s not the only reason why I recommend it…

Why upgrade your link in bio?
1- with over 31 million people who have a link in bio (all of which are very similar in structure), it’s a great way to set yourself apart — designing your own will capture attention
2- you can better brand the link in bio to reflect your uniqueness and reinforce your values and messaging + you can create an experience vs just a page to see links (go look at mine to see what I mean)
3- it’s better for SEO (google search not IG SEO) because you’re utilizing your own website — by having a linktree (or other apps) you’re adding an extra step for people to get to your website. More visitors you get directly to your website, the better 
4- having multiple links in a row causes decision paralysis (usually more than 5) — when you spread your links out in between graphics and pictures it can help break things up and minimize overwhelm + capture attention. And on top of that you can add more description to the offerings vs just a title on the link

Note: you don’t need to sell in all of these places! Choose 1 to implement and then move to the next or just choose 3 main ones to focus on— some of these things can be done multiple times, some can be automated & some are do once and leave it things 

EMAIL:
-nurture sequence → sales sequence: after someone opts in for your freebie, take them through a sequence of emails that provide value and warm them up to the topic of the offer you are going to pitch, then sell the offer in the sales sequence
-tripwire after opt-in form: present a low cost offer, like an ebook, for purchase after someone signs up for your freebie 
-a newsletter to your subscribers: think about something you teach inside your offer that is completely opposite of what some or all of your ideal customers believe or have tried. Think misconceptions or things you don’t agree with in your industry 
-guest email feature: do an email swap (collab) with someone in an adjacent niche to yours. You share education with their audience and then share your offer and they do the same

STORIES:
-question box: post a Q box asking current students in an offer to share something they love about it & then share the responses with a link at the end to join the offer OR put up a Q box asking people what is holding them back from joining the offer 
-close friends list: use your CF list as a place to sell even more (this is a great way to get more confident with selling) OR share additional BTS with your offer
-individual story: more content to come with selling on story info but one tangible tip you can implement today — share the origin story your offer. Why did you create? What was the moment you knew you wanted to create it? What events led up to the creation of the offer?
-story → DM: use your stories to start a conversation in DMs about your offer by having viewers reply with a specific word to get additional information. pro tip: give free value in the story then share about the offer in DMs

Maybe the answer isn’t selling more, it’s selling different 

I share a lot of content saying “sell daily” and I still stand by that but I had this epiphany the other day that selling more might not be the answer. The answer might be learning to sell different. Because here’s what I hear a lot… “I’m selling daily and no one is buying” or “I’m selling but it’s not resonating” 

So what’s the solution? How do you sell different?

Let’s dive into the 4 techniques (these are just 4 of many things you can do):

NUMBER 1
use analogies/metaphors: you can use them to simplify complex or uncommon concepts so they’re better understood, explain something in a way that is more familiar, or to share a mistake you see your audience make

Ex-
Instead of: building a strategy is key for growth

Try: building a strategy for growth is a lot like putting together a puzzle. The puzzle all put together is the goal and each piece is part of the strategy that will get you to the goal. 

NUMBER 2
use the law of reciprocity: this law isn’t about creating HAVE-to’s with your audience, it’s about creating WANT-to’s. Share free value so that people WANT to learn more (through your paid offer)

Ways to give: podcast episodes, content on social media, newsletter emails, freebies, events, giveaways

NUMBER 3
get specific with your language: don’t be afraid to target a specific need/issue with your copy. 

Ex- 
Instead of: learn to build your content pillars

Try: ditch the day-of content creation and random posting

Or ex 2-
Instead of: 30 quick exercises for moms

Try: exercises so quick you can fit them in while your baby is napping and so effective your pre baby jeans will be calling your name

NUMBER 4
lean into embodiment selling: most people are good at the talking the talk part which is sharing about what you sell — all the features, benefits, bonuses, etc. — but are you also good at the walking the walk part? Meaning are you a living breathing example of what you teach. You can be your own proof of concept and show your success. Think of methods, strategies, etc that you teach that you use daily or weekly in your own life

Let’s get a few things straight here…

Aesthetics? Yes. 
Perfectly curated feed? No. 

Have a visual identity? Yes.
Stress over how each post looks next to each other on your feed? No.

Have a put together feed? Yes.
Need to have a Pinterest board looking home/work space? No.

Content should have a similar vibe/feel? Yes.
Everything has to be edited to a T with presets? No.

Okay now let’s talk about why aesthetics matter…

NUMBER 1–
People, subconsciously, relate the quality of your content to the quality of your offers. You don’t see a bunch of blurry or poorly lit photos/videos and think “wow that offer/ product is high quality!”

NUMBER 2–
They help you to create visual recognition and make you memorable.

When you see the color pairing of green and white, what logo do you think of? Maybe Starbucks comes to mind

When you see red and white, what logo do you think of? Maybe Coca Cola comes to mine

Whether you thought of the two brands I mentioned or not, you thought of something and I can guess that the brands you thought of have consistent visual identity or else you would’ve have thought of them.

NUMBER 3–
Instagram is a visual platform - if it wasn’t it would be Twitter or threads. When was the last time you spent more than a few seconds on someone’s feed that wasn’t visually appealing? Or furthermore, when did you hit the follow button on an account like that last?

NUMBER 4–
First impressions are important. Just like with a first date, the first encounter with your feed needs to be positive or else people are not sticking around long enough to hit the follow button. But also, a big part of a good first impression is having a bingeable feed so your content needs to be easy to consume

So to sum it up- yes, aesthetics matter for both business (sales) and instagram growth but aesthetics ≠ perfectly curated and edited. And aesthetics isn’t the only thing that matters — having a bingeable feed is also important

All of the things listed above 100% help but the most important one is…

CREATING CONTENT YOUR AUDIENCE LIKES CONSUMING

Which is easier said than done for sure & MANY factors play into creating “good” content but the biggest reason why people aren’t engaging isn’t because you didn’t post at your optimal time. It’s because the content isn’t resonating 

Because here’s the truth… if you create high quality content that fills a need (informational, entertainment, inspirational) you won’t need to ask people to engage, they will on their own

Like really think about this… when was the last time you commented on a post & why? Was it because you saw a reel that touched on your heart strings and you went to tag someone in the comments that you knew would love it too? Or was it because you saw a post that had tips that were so helpful you wanted to say thank you to the creator for sharing?

You get my point — most of the time (most being the keyword here), we don’t engage because we’re asked. We engage because the content was so good we WANT to engage

So yes, use the CTAs (especially “comment __ and I’ll DM you ___”). Yes, get people to add you to their favorites feed. They all help and for some that is the only small tweak they need to increase engagement. But also, have an honest conversation with yourself about the content you’re posting because for most, that’s the underlying issue

Two scenarios…

1- people were engaging in the past, now they’re not

This tells me that you haven’t pivoted your content to fit your audiences current and changing needs OR that you haven’t pivoted the type and structure of content you create and it’s become predictable and too repetitive 

2- you’re posting consistently but haven’t ever gotten engagement

This tells me that you haven’t spent enough time experimenting with your content and content topics + looking at your analytics to adjust your content to make sure it resonates
